Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___

subdural hematoma

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:

History of Present Illness:
 MS ___ is a ___ F who was inpatient at the geriatric
psych unit at ___ when she sustained a fall with
headstrike around 6pm pn ___. She had been admitted to 
___
over the weekend for medication adjustments. Her family had
noticed that she had experienced a frequent number of falls
recently and was increasingly confused at night with vivid
hallucinations.  
She was transferred to ___ for neurosurgical evaluation.

___

Anxiety  
Several recent UTIs

___

Motor

a

Exam on Discharge
***
 
Pertinent Results:
___ NCHCT
The left parafalcine subdural hemorrhage is slightly larger 
compared with the immediate prior study with no significant mass 
effect or surrounding edema.  
The subdural hematoma extends inferiorly to the level of the 
tentorium. No additional sites of hemorrhage are identified. The 
ventricles and sulci are normal in size and configuration. There 
is no evidence of infarction or mass. 
  
No osseous abnormalities seen.  Trace mucosal thickening of the 
right 
maxillary sinus, and fluid-filled sphenoid sinuses are 
unchanged. The orbits are unremarkable. 
  
___
Degenerative changes. Likely old fracture of distal radius. 
Acute injury 
either at the level of the elbow joint or wrist cannot be 
excluded on these views, recommend clinical correlation consider 
dedicated elbow and/or wrist radiographs depending on site of 
symptoms. 

___ EKG
Probable sinus tachycardia with baseline artifact. Non-specific 
ST-T wave 
changes most pronounced in the inferior and anteroseptal leads. 
Compared to 
the previous tracing of ___ the heart rate has increased. The 
findings are 
otherwise similar. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ was transferred from ___ psych unit after 
a fall. NCHCT reportedly revealed a small SDH. Per report of OSH 
patient also had L radial fx. CT uploaded showed small 
parafalcine hemorrhage.

On ___ Patient was evaluated by ___ and OT who recommend rehab. A 
Repeat NCHCT was stable. A repeat xray of the radius revealed an 
old healed fracture but no acute injury. 

On ___ Patient was neurologically stable pending rehab 
placement. Given 500cc bolus for low urine output and poor PO 
intake.  

On ___, the patient became more agitated, requiring ativan in 
the evening with improvement in her mental status. 

On ___, the patient was alert and oriented to person and place, 
cooperative with exam. Agitation was resolved. 

On ___, the patient had reported foul-smelling urine. was 
otherwise stable. 

0n ___, exam was stable, patient was straight-cathed for 
urinalysis (given ongoing urinary incontinence) which was 
reassuring. Her labs however were notable for hypokalemia (2.8). 
An EKG was performed which was reassuring. Her K, Mg, Phos were 
repleted 

0n ___: exam was stable, patient continued to have poor PO 
intake, refusing some PO meds. K, Phos repleted. 

On ___ Electrolytes were all normal. She was evaluated by the 
geriactrics service who recommended decreasing remeron dose to 
stimulate appetite, decreased PRN IV ativan, and stopping 
keppra. They have also recommend ___ eval as an 
outpatient. Given patient has recieved a 8 day course of keppra 
this is quite reasonable. RN report concern for a day of loose 
stools. Patient has never been febrile and WBC count has never 
been elevated. Given these things cdiff is very unlikely. 
Patient was offered bed at rehab. She was discharged in stable 
condition with instructions for follow up. 
 
Medications on Admission:
seroquel, ativan, remeron, prilosec, sinemet, colace

Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Subdural hematoma

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - always.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Activity

·     We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, 
climbing, or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up 
appointment.

·     You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.

·     No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating 
medication. 

·     If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 

·     No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications

·     Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 

·     You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort 
if you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:

·     You may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, 
and remembering new information.

·     Emotional and/or behavioral difficulties are common. 

·     Feeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood 
swings are also common.

·     Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids 
and eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics 
(prescription pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool 
softener.

 

Headaches:

·     Headache is one of the most common symptom after a brain 
bleed. 

·     Most headaches are not dangerous but you should call your 
doctor if the headache gets worse, develop arm or leg weakness, 
increased sleepiness, and/or have nausea or vomiting with a 
headache. 

·     Mild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches 
but avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless 
prescribed by your doctor. 

·     There are other things that can be done to help with your 
headaches: avoid caffeine, get enough sleep, daily exercise, 
relaxation/ meditation, massage, acupuncture, heat or ice packs. 


When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:

·     Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the 
incision site. 

·     Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit

·     Nausea and/or vomiting

·     Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake

·     Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers

·     Seizures

·     Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak

·     Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or 
leg

 

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:

·     Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg

·     Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding

·     Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination

·     Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___

History of Present Illness:
___ y.o. female with Hep C/ETOH cirrhosis, who presented to ___ 
___ ___ with hematemesis.  Endoscopy revealed 
bleeding esophageal varices which were banded x 3 but she 
continued to bleed and required a repeat endoscopy the following 
day with three more bands placed to achieve hemostasis.  At 
least 1 liter of blood suctioned out of the stomach.  She was 
placed on prophylactic levofloxacin on day #1. She was 
hypotensive, and was rescuscitated with a total of 13 units 
PRBCs, 20 units PLTs, and 12 units FFP.  She remained 
hypotensive and required pressor (levophed).  She was intubated 
on hospital day #1 for airway protection.  Initially, she 
remained unresponsive off sedation, presumed due to hepatic 
encephalopathy.  She received lactulose and rifaxamin.  Over the 
next couple days, she stabilized hemodynamically and was weaned 
off pressor.  On ___ she had a tonic clonic seizure and 
received ativan.  CT head revealed large areas of brain edema in 
the parietal and temporal lobes.  Neurology was consulted and 
she received one dose of mannitol.  Her serum osm was 314.  She 
was transfered to ___ for further care.  
.
Of note, on the AM of transfer, she bit her ET tube when 
sedation was lightened and required paralytic to place a bite 
guard.  Also, just prior to transfer, sputum culture from ___ 
grew MRSA and she was begun on vancomycin.

- completed ___ rehab program, sober since

- hepatopulmonary syndrome, on home O2 at night (2L)

one brother is being considered as her liver donor

Initial CXR, portable ___:
PORTABLE SUPINE CHEST RADIOGRAPH:
The endotracheal tube is 2 cm from the carina, recommend pulling 
back between 2 and 3 cm. A nasogastric tube  terminates 
overlying the mid stomach with side port well beyond the GE  
junction. A right subclavian catheter terminates over the mid 
SVC. The lung volumes are low. The cardiomediastinal silhouette 
is stable. There is  consolidation of the left base either 
representing atelectasis or pneumonia.  There is a likely small 
associated left pleural effusion 
.
CT head ___:
IMPRESSION: Bilateral temporal lobe edema with effacement of the 
subjacent 
temporal horns of the lateral ventricle temporal horn of the 
lateral 
ventricles. There appears to be extension of edema into the left 
parietal 
region with mild sulcal effacement. Images from outside hospital 
would be 
useful to assess for interval change. 
ATTENDING NOTE: I think that the white matter hypodensity 
involves both 
cerebral hemispheres with predominent involvement of temporal 
lobes. 
Conditions such herpres encephgalitis should be considered in 
the differential but extensive involvement of frontal and 
parietal lobes is somewhat unusual. MRI can help for firther 
assessment. 
.
Abd u/s w/doppler ___:
IMPRESSION: 
1. Patent hepatic vasculature. 
2. Ascites. A mark was made at the left lower quadrant for 
paracentesis to 
be performed by the clinical staff. 
3. Small right pleural effusion. 
4. Splenomegaly. 
.
EEG ___:
IMPRESSION: This telemetry captured one electrographic seizure 
with 
onset in the left temporal region, which then spread to both 
hemispheres 
and lasted for about two minutes. The background activity in 
wakefulness 
showed bursts of generalized slowing and occasional left 
posterior 
quadrant slowing. 
.
___ CT-A Head:
IMPRESSION: 
1. Normal CT angiography and CT venography with no vascular 
stenosis or 
occlusion, and no venous thrombosis. 
2. Unchanged diffuse hypodensity throughout white matter tracts 
symmetrically involving both temporal, and, to a lesser extent, 
frontal lobes. The findings are suggestive of cerebral edema due 
to a systemic or metabolic cause, including liver failure or 
related metabolic abnormalities. 

___ EEG
Impression: This 24 hour video EEG telemetry captured no 
electrographic 
seizures or pushbutton activations. Automated and routine 
sampling 
demonstrated periods of generalized slowing consistent with an 
underlying encephalopathy. Occasional periods of slowing were 
seen in 
the temporal parietal leads consistent with more focal regions 
of 
underlying cortical or subcortical dysfunction. 
.
___ CT Head
IMPRESSION: 
1. Unchanged diffuse hypodensity involving the white matter 
tracts 
predominantly involving the temporal lobe, also involving the 
frontal lobes. The differential diagnosis includes cerebral 
edema due to the liver failure. Other white matter disease 
cannot be excluded. MRI of the head is the best modality for 
evaluation of the white matter disease and cerebral edema. 
2. No other acute intracranial pathology is identified. 
.
___ EEG
IMPRESSION: This telemetry captured no ongoing seizure activity. 
Routine 
samplings showed a background suggestive of an encephalopathy 
involving 
both superficial and deeper structures and additional slowing in 
the 
left mid-temporal region. 
.
___ EEG
IMPRESSION: This telemetry captured no clinical or 
electrographic 
seizures. The background activity was slow with additional 
bursts of 
generalized slowing suggestive of an encephalopathy and with 
focal 
slowing and sharp and slow wave complexes in the left temporal 
and 
posterior areas. 
.
___ MRI
IMPRESSION: 
1. Abnormal T2- and FLAIR-signal identified bilaterally, most 
intense at the insular cortex. Abnormal signal also seen in the 
medial and inferior temporal lobes, bilaterally. Findings raise 
the possibility of herpetic or other viral encephalitis, though 
there is no restricted diffusion or hemorrhage. 
2. Signal abnormality appears to involve more than simply the 
white matter 
tracts, with involvement of the insular cortex as well as the 
cortex in the temporal lobes. This more global picture again 
raises concern for previous hypoxic/anoxic brain injury, 
possibly with secondary acute demyelination. 
.
___ CXR
Nasogastric tube terminates in body of the stomach and is no 
longer coiled.  Endotracheal tube has apparently been removed. 
Examination is otherwise without change except for improving 
aeration at the lung bases with associated slight increase in 
lung volumes.
.
___ EEG
IMPRESSION: This is a normal routine EEG in the waking and 
drowsy 
states. There were no focal lateralized or epileptiform features 
noted 
.
___ CXR
Bibasilar atelectasis are grossly unchanged. Cardiac size is top 
normal. 
There are low lung volumes. There is no pleural effusion. NG 
tube tip is in the stomach. 
.

WBC 4

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y.o. female with Hep C and alcoholic cirrhosis, initially 
admitted to ___ with variceal bleeding, 
stabilized endoscopically, but then developed altered mental 
status, presumed due to hepatic encephalopathy, and intubated 
for airway protection. Subseuqently found to have cerebral 
edema, transferred to ___ for further care. Hospital course by 
system:
.
# Neuro: Pt had acutely AMS at OSH and was found to have 
developed cerebral edema after her initial variceal bleed. 
Initialy, her AMS was attributed to severe hepatic 
encephalopathy. However, this was not typical for her, as she 
had previously had relatively well-compensated liver disease. 
Head CT revealed the cerebral edema. Nonetheless, she was 
continued on lactulose and rifaxamin for any contribution of 
hepatic encephalopathy to her AMS. TSH was checked and was 
normal. Also considered were infectious encephalopathies (ie 
HSV, bacterial). CT head upon arrival to ___ MICU revealed 
bilateral cerebral edema, primarily of the temporal lobes, most 
concerning for HSV encephalitis. Due to her extensive cerebral 
edeam, an LP could not be performed.  Neurology was consulted 
and recommeded EEG and empiric coverage for HSV encephalitis 
with acyclovir (10mg/kg Q8H).  No recommendation was made for 
mannitol initially given her sodium of > 150, but when sodium 
dropped below 150 on ___, several doses of mannitol were 
given.  Serum Osm was in the low 300s.  Neuro recommended 
stopping mannitol on ___, and starting hypertonic saline 
instead to reach sodium goal 150-155.  Sodium and serum 
osmolarity monitored Q6H. The MICU team also emperically covered 
for bacterial meningitis with CTX/Vancomycin, beginning ___.  
Her continuous EEG showed evidence of seizure activity at that 
time, and she was loaded with Keppra and maintenance dose begun. 
Serial repeat 24h video EEGs showed no further seziures, 
although she remained intubated and on propofol. Serial head 
imaging revealed stable cerebral edema but no evidence of CVA. 
On ___ a head MRI revealed not only diffuse bitemporal 
abnormailties as previously seen, but also extension into the 
grey matter, concerning for prior anoxic brain injury. 
Eventually neuro agreed with d/c'ing hypertonic saline and 
letting sodium drift down to 140 (but not below). When her 
mental status appeared improved, she was extubated on ___. She 
had no subsequent problems protecting her airway, but remained 
forgetful and altered. A repeat EEG was ordered per neurology to 
re-evaluate for subclinical seizure, which was without any 
evidence of seizure. Her prognosis is uncertain as to recovery 
from her anoxic brain injury, and she is left with significant 
mental deficits (oriented to person only at time of transfer). 
She is to followup with behavioral neurology next month.
.
# Respiratory:  Initially was intubated at OSH for airway 
protection after she became confused, felt ___ hepatic 
encephalopathy, later felt to be cerebral edema (see above). 
However, was noted at OSH to have fever and grew MRSA in sputum, 
so was started on Vanco on ___ for a MRSA pneumonia. Also of 
significance, at baseline, the patient has hepatopulmonary 
syndrome with PaO2 in the ___. At ___, her ventilator settings 
were changed to ARDSNET settings, and her FIO2 was progressively 
weaned. VAP precautions initiated. Culture data remained 
negative except for the MRSA in sputum from OSH and from intial 
presentation here. She completed a 2 week course of vancomycin 
and remained afebrile subsequently. When her mental status was 
felt to be clearer, she was successfully extubated on ___. She 
is comfortable on nasal cannula at time of transfer. Note should 
be made to avoid upright positioning for extended periods of 
time due to hepatopulmonary syndrome and orthodeoxia. ******Her 
baseline O2 sats are in the upper ___
.
# GI/Liver - Initial presentation to ___ showed 
bleeding ___ esophageal varices and she was stabilized with 
volume resuscitation.  In total, received 13 units PRBCs, 12 
units FFP, 20 units PLTs at ___.  She had 3 bands placed 
by EGD on ___, and repeat banding x 3 on ___.  She was 
hemodynamically stable upon transfer and remained so in the MICU 
at ___.  She was continued on IV protonix ___ and monitored 
with ___ HCTs. She was also started on post-GIB SBP ppx with 
cipro after her broader antibiotics (vanc/ctx) were d/c'ed once 
bacterial meningitis was felt to be unlikely. A beta blocker was 
added for post-bleed ppx. Diagnostic paracentesis on admission 
___ was negative for SBP. She was not stooling initially; 
given lactulose Q1H until she began stooling.  Later lactulose 
dose tapered. Rifaximin added.
.
# ID - initially was broadly covered out of concern for 
meningitis with vanc/CTX/acyclovir. She was also being treated 
for documented MRSA PNA with vancomycin. When bacterial 
meningitis was felt to be unlikely, the CTX was d/c'ed, but she 
completed a 2 week course of vanc for the MRSA PNA. She remains 
on acyclovir for a planned 3 week course per ID and neurology 
(___). She was briefly on ciprofloxacin for post-GIB sepsis 
ppx.
.
# Heme - has thrombocytopenia Likely ___ liver disease.  
Received several platelet transfusion at ___ hosptial, 
but none at ___.
.
# Psych - has depression, held meds given mental status
.
# PPx: pneumoboots, PPI
.
# CODE: FULL, confirmed
.

-- CVL changed upon arrival to ___, then d/c'ed ___ after

.

Discharge Instructions:
You were transferred to ___ 
after suffering a gastrointestinal bleed due to your liver 
disease. You lost a lot of blood at ___, but 
they were able to stop the bleeding. However, you suffered 
swelling around the brain which necessitated intubation. You 
were transferred to us seriously ill. You were treated for a 
possible infection of your brain, and will be finishing a course 
of medicine for this at your rehab. Your lung function returned 
to your baseline level. 
.
Unfortunately, MRI scans of your head showed evidence of anoxic 
(lack of blood flow) brain injury, which may have occcurred from 
either blood loss or swelling around the brain. Our neurologists 
followed you closely and are uncertain of the extent of recovery 
that is possible. They would like you to follow up with them as 
follows.

Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___

Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs

Chief Complaint:
word finding difficulties, fever, weakness, incontinence
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ M w/ recently diagnosed metastatic squamous 
cell carcinoma, presumably of lung origin, with widely 
metastatic disease to bone who presented to the ER today with 
word finding difficulties, urinary incontinence, fever and 
increased weakness. His SNF felt that his mental status was 
worse, starting last night. His VS were stable, with T 98.1, BP 
120/66, HR 97, RR 20 and sats 93% on RA. Exam was notable for R 
leg weakness and inability for him to speak more than 2 coherent 
sentences. Per their report, he denied any abdominal pain, 
fevers, or chills. 
.
In the ER, he was seen by both ortho-spine and neurology and 
underwent an MRI of his spine which showed worsening of the 
disease in his spine, extending through the cortex of the sacrum 
and into the left and right iliac bone with severe narrowing at 
S1. There is also a new pathologic L3 fracture with retropulsion 
onto the cord. Ortho-spine did not appreciate any change in his 
weakness and recommended XRT to his spine. They recommended 
against the use of steroids, given his fever and possible 
infection and no evidence of cord compression on MRI. Neurology 
was also consulted and recommended an MRI of his head to 
evaluate for metastases or some other etiology for his word 
finding difficulties. CT head noncontrast was negative. He 
spiked a temperature to 101.7 in the ER shortly after arrival 
and was treated with CTX, vanco, levaquin. He also received 2L 
NS. 
.  
Review of Systems:  
(+) as per HPI - pt unable to fully cooperate with full ROS

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y.o. F with type 2 diabetes mellitus, hepatitis C complicated 
by cirrhosis, varices, hepatic encephalopathy, and HCC, 
presented to ___ on morning of admission with 
shakiness found to have hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.  
.  
# Confusion: Etiologies were thought to include could include 
hepatic encephalopathy, infection, toxic metabolic from 
hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, or less likely metastatic disease. 
It was ultimately believed that her confusion was secondary to 
the patient not taking her insulin or eating in the morning. She 
was continued on rifaximin, and her blood sugar was kept under 
good control. Her mental status cleared and she was alert and 
oriented x 3 at time of discharge.
.  
# Hyponatremia: Believed to be complication of cirrhosis. There 
were no signs of CHF or renal failure. Cortisol level was 
normal. The patient was normonatremic at time of discharge.
.  
# Hyperkalemia: The patient was treated for her hyperkalemia in 
the Emergency Department. Etiologies were thought to include 
dietary indiscretion, spironolactone effect, bactrim therapy for 
UTI, and/or insulin deficiency. EKG's showed now peaked T waves 
or other concerning changes. She was educated about low 
potassium diet. She was also discharged on a reduced dose of 
spironolactone, in addition to low-dose furosemide.  
.  
# Blood on toilet paper: The patient reported this while in the 
Emergency Department. To admitting housestaff, however, she 
denied this. Her hematocrit and hemodynamics were stable.
.  
#UTI: The patient completed a seven day course of bactrim on the 
day of admission.
.
# End Stage Liver Disease ___ Hepatitis C; Hepatocellular 
Carcinoma: LFTs were at baseline. She was continued on 
propanolol and rifaximin per outpt regimen. Management of her 
HCC was deferred to the outpatient setting.
.
# Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: The patient was written for a 
diabetic diet and was placed on her home regimen of lantus and

through the ED with a right foot abscess on ___. The abscess 
had been drained by Dr. ___ in clinic. The patient was 
admitted to the podiatric surgery service for intravenous 
antibiotics and possible surgical debridement. However, it was 
determined that surgical debridement would not be necessary as 
the wound appeared stable after the abscess was drained. 
Therefore, patient simply received local wound care as well as 
IV antibiotics with a plan in place to apply wound VAC to the 
right foot once outpatient. The patient's home medications were 
continued throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked 
with ___ who determined that discharge to home with ___ services 
was appropriate. The ___ hospital course was otherwise 
unremarkable.
At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, wound was stable in appearance, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
NWB to the right lower extremity. The patient will follow up 
with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough discussion was had with 
the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge 
course including reasons to call the office or return to the 
hospital, and all questions were answered. The patient was also 
given written instructions concerning precautionary instructions 
and the appropriate follow-up care. The patient expressed 
readiness for discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___. You were admitted 
to the Podiatric Surgery service for a right foot infection. You 
were given IV antibiotics while here. You are being discharged 
home with the following instructions: 

ACTIVITY:
There are restrictions on activity. Please remain non weight 
bearing to your R foot until your follow up appointment. You may 
place weight on your left foot, but would try to avoid it if 
possible. You should keep this site elevated when ever possible 
(above the level of the heart!) 

No driving until cleared by your Surgeon.

PLEASE CALL US IMMEDIATELY FOR ANY OF THE FOLLOWING PROBLEMS:
Redness in or drainage from your leg wound(s).
New pain, numbness or discoloration of your foot or toes.
Watch for signs and symptoms of infection. These are: a fever 
greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or pus 
draining from the incision site. If you experience any of these 
or bleeding at the incision site, CALL THE DOCTOR.

Exercise:
Limit strenuous activity for 6 weeks.
No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next ___ days.
Try to keep leg elevated when able.

BATHING/SHOWERING:
You may shower immediately upon coming home, but you must keep 
your dressing CLEAN, DRY and INTACT. You can use a shower bag 
taped around your ankle/leg or hang your foot/leg outside of the 
bathtub. 

Avoid taking a tub bath, swimming, or soaking in a hot tub for 4 
weeks after surgery or until cleared by your physician.

MEDICATIONS:
Unless told otherwise you should resume taking all of the 
medications you were taking before surgery. 
Remember that narcotic pain meds can be constipating and you 
should increase the fluid and bulk foods in your diet. (Check 
with your physician if you have fluid restrictions.) If you feel 
that you are constipated, do not strain at the toilet. You may 
use over the counter Metamucil or Milk of Magnesia. Appetite 
suppression may occur; this will improve with time. Eat small 
balanced meals throughout the day. 

DIET:
There are no special restrictions on your diet postoperatively. 
Poor appetite is not unusual for several weeks and small, 
frequent meals may be preferred.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENT:
Be sure to keep your medical appointments. 
If a follow up appointment was not made prior to your discharge, 
please call the office on the first working day after your 
discharge from the hospital to schedule a follow-up visit. This 
should be scheduled on the calendar for seven to fourteen days 
after discharge. Normal office hours are ___ 
through ___.
PLEASE FEEL FREE TO CALL THE OFFICE WITH ANY OTHER CONCERNS OR 
QUESTIONS THAT MIGHT ARISE.

# Acute renal failure on Chronic Kidney disease:
Baseline creatinine in the ___ range with episodes of 
elevation to 3.0.  The patient was given IV fluids with 
improvement in her creatinine to 2.6. The patient was seen by 
nephrology who discussed with the patient's outpatient 
nephrologist. SPEP was sent and showed only 
hypogammaglobulinemia. The patient likely has underlying CKD 
with changes in her renal function related to volume status. She 
was advised to continue to measure her urine output and to have 
repeat urine studies as an outpatient. 

# Diarrhea: To date has been attributed to small bowel resection 
and SIBO. Longstanding, refractory to supportive outpatient 
care, based on rising Cr appears unable to maintain adequate 
intake even with frequent IVF boluses via port. The patient was 
followed by gastroenterology. Stool studies were checked which 
were negative. She had a ttG which was normal. Upper GI series 
with small bowel follow through showed rapid movement of barium 
into the small bowel confirming short gut syndrome. The 
patient's diarrhea improved during her hospitalization. She was 
advised to take creon- open the capusles 15 minutes before 
meals. She was also advised to cook with MCT oil and to use 
liquid loperamide to help control her diarrhea as an outpatient.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___, 
___ were admitted to the hospital for evaluation of visual 
disturbance on your left. It was determined that ___ had a 
stroke on the right side of your head, in the parietal and 
temporal lobes. The most likely cause for this is an emboli, 
likely from the right carotid artery. Carotid ultrasounds show a 
less than 40% occlusion of the right carotid artery. Please 
start taking the medicine Aggrenox. This medicine will help

CT-GUIDED ABSCESS DRAINAGE ___:
CT FINDINGS: 
Patient is known with a large superficial skin ulceration 
overlying the right hip.  Underneath this ulceration there are 
two linear collections 
communicating between them and going to that ulcer; the more 
superficial one contains a fat-fluid level and measures 11.5 x

in the subcutaneous fat and goes up to the gluteus muscle.  
There is also a small collection in the anterior portion of the 
right maximus gluteus muscle (series 3, image 38) measuring 17 x 
27 mm. The greater trochanter lies just beneath the collection.  
There is minimal irregularity of the cortex but which is similar 
to the other side.  There is no significant sign of 
osteomyelitis. 
There is significant degenerative change of the spine with 
anterolisthesis of L4 over L5 measuring 7 mm. 
Multiple gallstones are seen without sign of cholecystitis.  
Small and large bowel of the pelvis are unremarkable.  A Foley 
catheter is in the bladder. The uterus is unremarkable.  There 
is a rectal and uterine prolapse. 
PROCEDURE: 
It was decided to aspirate and drain the more superficial 
collection which should be in continuity with the deepest one. 
The procedure risks and benefits and alternatives were discussed 
with the 
patient and written informed consent was obtained.  A 
preprocedure timeout was performed, discussing the planned 
procedure, confirming the patient's identity with three 
identifiers and reviewing a checklist per ___ protocol. 
The patient was placed on left lateral decubitus on the CT table 
to access the subcutaneous right hip collection.  Under CT 
guidance, an entrance site was selected and the skin was prepped 
and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  5 cc of lidocaine 1% 
was instilled for local anesthesia.  A 5 ___ ___ catheter 
needle was first inserted into the collection where 30 cc of pus 
was removed and sent to microbiology.  Then by a more anterior 
approach with an 18 gauge ___ needle, ___ wire was put 
into the collection and 6 ___ catheter was then inserted. 
Deep sedation was provided by the anesthesia, please refer to 
their note for further detail.  There was no complication after 
the procedure. 
IMPRESSION: 
CT-guided placement of a 6 ___ catheter inside the soft 
tissue abcess 
overlyng the right hip.  Pus was removed from the collection and 
sent to 
microbiology. 
.

Ms. ___ is an ___ with a hx ___ body dementia, AF (not

# R thigh abscess, infected bursitis, osteomyelitis ___ proteus 
Patient developed a right thigh abscess in the setting of a 
large pressure ulcer on the lateral right thigh. Abscess was 
likely present during prior admission (vs. superinfected sp 
bursa bx done on prior admission). Initially, fevers were 
attributed to sacral decubitus ulcer, and ACS was consulted to 
perform a bed-side debridement. Debridement on ___ revealed 
a clean-based sacral ulcer, which did not probe to bone. Given 
this, patient was scheduled to undergo US-guided biopsy of R 
thigh (swollen area on upper right thigh which was previously 
found to contain sterile bursitis). Repeat U/S was concerning 
for possible abscess. Pt underwent CT-guided aspiration of R 
thigh abscess under anesthesia (on ___ and surgical bedside 
debridement of R thigh abscess (on ___. She also underwent 
operative debridement and bone biopsy (on ___. She was treated 
with flagyl (___) and Vancomycin/Cefepime (___). She 
was evaluated by infectious disease and, after tissue culture 
from bone showed proteus growth, she was transitioned to PO 
monotherapy with Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO bid (day 1 = ___ with 
a plan to continue treatment until ___. Nutritional status 
remained tenuous and pt's diet was liberalized. Patient was 
evaluated by S+S, who recommedned ground dysphagia diet until 
re-assessment at a time when pt was able to obtain her dentures. 
Calorie counts were inconsistent but, with family's 
encouragement, pt was able to eat large meals. She was 
discharged with follow-up at Surgery clinic for further 
management of the R thigh wound.

Pt has a Stage IV sacral ulcer. As above, pt underwent

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
It was a pleasure taking care of you here at ___ 
___. You were admitted to our hospital 
after undergoing laparoscopic sigmoid colectomy. You have 
recovered from surgery and are now ready to be discharged to 
home. Please follow the recommendations below to ensure a speedy 
and uneventful recovery. 
 
ACTIVITY:
- Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
- You may climb stairs. 
- You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit.
- Don't lift more than 10 lbs for 6 weeks. (This is about the 
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to 
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
- You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
- You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
- Heavy exercise may be started after 6 weeks, but use common 
sense and go slowly at first.
- You may resume sexual activity unless your doctor has told you 
otherwise.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
- You may feel weak or "washed out" for 6 weeks. You might want 
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
- You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
- You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
You might feel somewhat depressed.
- You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
- All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time. If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
- Your incision may be slightly red around the edges. This is 
normal.
- If you have steri strips, do not remove them for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that are on your incision.) But 
if they fall off before that that's okay).
- You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
- It is normal to feel a firm ridge along the incision. This 
will go away.
- Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
- Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
- You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid 
staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, 
please call your surgeon.
- You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
- Over the next ___ months, your incision will fade and become 
less prominent.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
- You may take a stool softener such as Colace. You can get this 
medicine without a prescription.
- If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon.
- After some operations, diarrhea can occur. If you get 
diarrhea, don't take anti-diarrhea medicines. Drink plenty of 
fluids and see if it goes away. If it does not go away, or is 
severe and you feel ill, please call your surgeon.
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
- It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
- Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
- Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
- If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
- Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you 
cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the folloiwng, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
- Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just 
as you did before, unless you have been told differently.
- You may take Tylenol ___ every 8 hours and you may take 
Ibuprofen 400-600mg every 6 hours. You may find it helpful to 
alternate these medications.
- If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not 
to take, please call your surgeon.

Brief Hospital Course:
HOSPITAL COURSE
This is a ___ year old gentleman with complex medical issues, 
including recent hospitalization for medically managed 
cholecystitis, presenting with chest pain, found to be in atrial 
fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and admitted to 
Medicine. Patient was transferred to the CCU for monitoring 
after pericardiocentesis (no tamponade physiology on echo, 
procedure performed for diagnostic purposes), who subsequently 
developed fever and hypotension requiring pressure support with 
phenylephrine. He ultimately opted for re-focus of medical 
management to pain management and positioning therapy and was 
discharged to a rehabilitation facility.
.
ACTIVE ISSUES
# GOALS OF CARE: After significant discussion with both his 
family and his medical providers the patient voiced his desire 
for re-focus of his medical management to control of his pain, 
and focus on comfort. These discussions arose in the setting of 
initiation of permanent dialysis and prolonged and profound 
physical and emotional decompensation. The patient stated he 
understood that termination of dialysis would not be compatible 
with life. The patient was transferred to a rehabilitation 
facility for management of pain and positioning therapy.
.
# PERICARDIAL EFFUSION: Echo performed on admission demonstrated 
large circumferential pericardial effusion, no evidence of 
tamponade. Since the patient had been having transient episodes 
of hypotension during HD sessions, and in order to better 
clarify the etiology of the pericardial fluid, a 
pericardiocentesis was performed. Per report, 260 cc of yellow 
serous fluid was removed. Two hours post-procedure the patient 
became hypotensive, initially responding to fluid boluses, then 
requiring Neo for pressure support. He was pan-cultured and 
started on broad antibiotics- vancomycin, cefepime and 
metronidazole. It was noted that his pericardial fluid changed 
in nature from serous to cloudy pink thick fluid. He then became 
febrile, and received more volume resuscitation for likely 
septic shock.  Studies were consistent with an exudative 
effusion and culture grew vancomycin resistant enterococcus. 
Broad spectrum antibiotics were discontinued and daptomycin was 
started. The source remained unclear, given nothing on imaging 
to support contiguous spread, and highly unlikely that the 
procedure introduced the organism. Furthermore, blood and urine 
cultures were negative throughout his hospital stay. A TEE was 
negative for evidence of valvular vegetations. Repeat imaging 
showed the effusion was resolved and the pericardial drain was 
removed. He was treated with a 5 day course of Daptomycin before 
antibiotics were discontinued on discharge following the wishes 
of the patient.
.
# HYPOTENSION: The patient was noted to be hypotensive on 
admission, thought to be secondary to hypovolemia from poor PO 
intake. He also had a recent history of transient hypotension 
during hemodialysis for which he was started on midodrine. 
Echocardiogram revealed an enlarged pericardial effusion 
(details above). Post-pericardiocentesis the patient was treated 
with fluid resuscitation and broad antibiotics for presumed 
septic shock. His blood pressure was supported with 
phenylephrine. A ___ test was negative for adrenal 
insufficiency.  Additionally, albumin of 1.7 so likely has poor 
intravascular osmotic pressure. Given his history of recent 
medically-managed cholecystitis, and known intra-abdominal fluid 
collections, a CT torso was obtained to investigate potential 
sources of infection. His HD catheter was removed. Surgery was 
consulted to investigate possible cholecystitis (details below), 
and ___ performed a drainage of an intraabdominal fluid 
collection, a hematoma. Serial blood and urine cultures were 
negative. His hypotension resolved, and he was weaned off 
phenylephrine prior to discharge. His midodrine was increased to 
5 TID. Medical management was discontinued as the patient 
declined further medical management.
.  
# SUSPECTED CHOLECYSTITIS: The patient had a recent history of 
medically-managed cholecystitis. On admission he was initially 
treated with broad spectrum antibiotics, which were then 
narrowed to Levaquin. Given our clinical concern for sepsis, a 
RUQ ultrasound was obtained and demonstrated a sludge-filled 
gallbladder and a small, unchanged fluid collection. CT torso 
demonstrated stranding, concerning for acute cholecystitis. 
Surgery was consulted and recommended HIDA scan given low 
suspicion on physical exam. HIDA scan was positive and a 
percutaneous drain was attempted; however, the procedure was 
complicated by collapse of the gallbladder (inconsistent with 
acute cholecystitis) and development of a small hematoma. A 
drain was placed in the abdominal fluid collection, which 
appeared to be an old hematoma. Microbiology was sent and was 
negative for growth. The drain was removed.  
.
# ESRD on HD: The patient normally receives HD on ___. 
Renal was consulted. HD initially was on hold given new pressor 
requirement and stable electrolytes. Given concern for sepsis, 
the tunneled dialysis catheter was removed and replaced with a 
temporary catheter. Once stable, the patient received CVVH with 
phenylephrine for pressure support. Culture of the catheter tip 
revealed no growth. A permanent catheter was not placed as the 
patient declined further dialysis.
.
# ATRIAL FIBRILLATION with RAPID VENTRICULAR RESPONSE: Present 
on admission. The patient spontaneously cardioverted and 
remained in sinus for the rest of his admission. The patient has 
___ S2 score of 3; however, given his history of 
intraabdominal hematomas, we elected to continue aspirin 325 for 
anticoagulation. Medical management was discontinued as the 
patient declined further medical management.
.
# CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE: Presented with CP in setting of AF 
with RVR, found to have ST changes and elevated troponin 
consistent with demand ischemia. Enzymes were cycled and the 
patient ruled out for an acute myocardial infarction. We 
continued his aspirin and statin. Medical management was 
discontinued as the patient declined further medical management.
.
# ANEMIA: No evidence of acute bleeding. Likely secondary to 
chronic inflammation. Is on Aranesp as outpatient. Hct trended 
down initially on admission and was stable around 20 at the time 
of discharge. He required a transfusion of 1 unit of pRBCs with 
appropriate response.
.  
# THROMBOCYTOPENIA: Relatively stable. Unclear etiology, 
reportedly has chronic ITP, and is status post splenectomy.  
.
# PERIPHERAL NEUROPATHY: Continued on gabapentin 100 qhs. 
Medical management was discontinued as the patient declined 
further medical management.
.
# GASTROPARESIS: Continued on metoclopramide 5 mg PO QIDACHS. 
Medical management was discontinued as the patient declined 
further medical management.
.
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
- ___ Management: Management of pain and optimization of 
positional comfort.
- Pending Studies: Pericardial and Abdominal Fluid Cytology, 
finalized culture data
- Code Status: DNR/DNI, do not resuscitate.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with history of AF, HTN, 
hyperlipidemia, and s/p
an old left MCA infarct with residual aphasia and mild right 
sided weakness.  He was found confused, then suddenly collapsed 
per his wife earlier today.  He was taken to ___ 
___, where head CT showed an ICH. He was intubated, loaded 
with phosphenytoin & treated with vitamin K for presumed 
coagulopathy; then transferred to ___ for surgical management 
of his ICH.
.
Upon transfer from the outside hospital, the patient was 
initially evaluated by the neurosurgery service in regards to a 
possible right temporoparietal craniotomy.  In lengthy 
discussion with the neurosurgery service and neurology service, 
the family decided against surgical intervention as they did not 
want the patient to suffer.  
.
The neurology service was asked to see him urgently by 
Neurosurgery to assist with ICH management and to render our 
opinion regarding the futility of surgical intervention.  At 
time of examination, the patient had no spontaneous movement and 
did not respond to voice.  He had a mild gag reflex. Pupils were 
small ~ 1 to 1.5 mm but reactive.  Eyes were midline.  He had 
corneals bilaterally.  Doll's eye was not elicited.  He moved 
the right side to pain & nasal stimulation. He postures on the 
left in response to pain.  Toes were upgoing. Overall, his GCS 
was 4.  Head CT showed a large right parenchymal ICH with IVH 
and extension into the brainstem, midline shift of ~ 22mm, and 
ventricular dilatation in addition to an old left
temporo-parietal infarct. 
.
Overall, the cause of his ICH was difficult to ascertain.  It is 
likely hypertensive, but one cannot entirely rule out a 
secondary cause.  Regardless, his prognosis appeared grim. His 
ICH score was 4, indicating a 30-day mortality of ~ 97%.  
Multiple members of the neurology and neurosurgery service had 
lengthy discussions with multiple family members regarding his 
condition, expected prognosis, and treatment options.  His 
chances for any meaningful recovery, if he survives, are 
minimal.  While surgery could be life-saving, it is unlikely to 
improve his functional outcome. They decided on a DNR status, 
but wanted to
discuss the surgical option with Dr. ___ further.  They 
were initially inclined to proceed with surgery, but later 
reversed their decision.
.
The patient was admitted to the NSICU for medical management.  A 
repeat CT head several hours after arrival revealed worsening 
hemorrhage with midline shift and uncal herniation.  Social work 
consult was requested to help the family cope with the difficult 
situation and after further discussions, the patient was 
ultimately made CMO.  He was pronoucned dead at ___ at 6:20 
AM.
.

diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and denied pain.

You were admitted to ___ with abdominal pain. A repeat CT scan 
showed that the inflammation from your appendicitis is all 
improving. You were placed on bowel rest and given antibiotics. 
Your pain is now improved and your lab work is normal. You are 
tolerating a regular diet. You are medically cleared to be 
discharged home to continue your recovery. Please note the 
following instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Weight BEar as tolerated

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Edoxaban 

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

# Atypical chest pain 
Patient presented with substernal chest pain that then migrated 
to epigastric area, with report from EMS of afib w/ RVR seen on 
initial evaluation. Associated with SOB and within the last 2 
days palpitations which are new. Difficult to obtain clear 
history from patient due to language barrier but did not sound 
cardiac in origin. Troponin 0.01 x3. EKG with some anterolateral 
q waves but not particularly convincing for ischemic changes. No 
evidence of pericarditis on EKG, had recent V/Q scan that ruled 
out PE. Pulmonology had been consulted on previous admission and 
do not feel chest pain related to lung pathology. ETT on ___ 
was negative for ischemia. Patient had been being treated for 
active H. pylori infection and completed 10 day course of 
antibiotics ___. Spoke to GI who said that patient should be 
trialed on high dose PPI for at least 8 weeks and monitor for 
resolution of pain. If pain is still refractory, PCP should 
refer to GI for further work-up. Omeprazole increased from 20mg 
to 40mg BID. Patient without further chest pain during 
hospitalization.

# Atrial tachycardia 
Initially thought that patient had atrial fibrillation prior to 
admission as was noted in field by EMS but no strips showing 
irregular rhythm in chart. No prior history of a-fib. Evening of 
___, patient was symptomatic with palpitations and found to 
have atrial tachycardia to 130s. Unclear trigger but could be 
due to underlying pneumoconiosis and chronic cough. TSH normal 
at 0.27. Started metoprolol for rate control ___. Will be 
discharged on metoprolol XL 50mg daily. Can reassess need for 
medication in 3 months. 

# Small pericardial effusion
TTE done ___ which showed normal biventricular cavity size and 
systolic function (LVEF 67%). There was a note of a small, 
circulferential pericardial effusion with no signs of tampenade. 
Likely secondary to chronic inflammation in setting of 
underlying lung problems but should have follow-up TTE in 4 to 6 
weeks to ensure resolution.

# Pleural effusions 
# Pneumoconiosis w/ hilar LAD and lung nodules 
# Dyspnea
# Non-productive cough

pleural effusions. Endorsed dyspnea but still oxygenating well

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

___ you very much for allowing us to care for you during your 
hospitalization at the ___.

WHAT HAPPENED DURING MY HOSPITAL STAY?
- You had chest pain and we did a study called an exercise 
stress test which showed that the pain was not coming from your 
heart.
-Your chest pain is likely from your stomach infection called H. 
pylori for which you have completed 10 days of antibiotic 
medications. We increased the dose of your acid blocking 
medication called omeprazole from 20mg twice a day to 40mg twice 
a day. You should continue this medication for 8 weeks and let 
your primary care doctor know if you continue to have pain.
- You were found to have an abnormal heart rhythm called atrial 
tachycardia and were started on a medication called metoprolol 
to control your heart rate
- You had some trouble breathing and were seen by lung 
specialists who recommended that you start a medication called 
albuterol to help you breathe better
- You were also evaluated by the bronchoscopy doctors who 
recommended starting an albuterol inhaler and 5 days of steroids 
to reduce your lung inflammation. This should help with your 
cough and shortness of breath.

WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME?
- Continue taking the metoprolol every day to control your heart 
rate. You should follow-up with your primary care doctor who can 
monitor your heart rate and determine if this medication is 
still needed.
- You should continue taking the albuterol as prescribed for 
your shortness of breath
- It is important that you take the omeprazole as this 
medication helps to prevent stomach damage from acid and reduce 
your chest discomfort.
- You should stop taking your amlodipine (medication for high 
blood pressure) as you no longer need this medication.
- Continue taking all your medications as prescribed on this 
discharge document.
- Follow-up with your primary care doctor. We will make an 
appointment for you.

We wish you the best,
Your ___ care team

Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or go to the emergency department if:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*You develop new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or 
wheeze.
*You are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons.  Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience an unusual discharge.
*Your pain is not improving within 12 hours or is not under 
control within 24 hours.
*Your pain worsens or changes location.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*You develop any concerning symptoms.

General Discharge Instructions:
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication.  Please take any 
new medications as prescribed.
Please take the prescribed analgesic medications as needed.  You 
may not drive or heavy machinery while taking narcotic analgesic 
medications.  You may also take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as 
directed, but do not exceed 4000 mg in one day.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk several times per 
day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.  Avoid strenuous 
physical activity and refrain from heavy lifting greater than 10 
lbs., until you follow-up with your surgeon, who will instruct 
you further regarding activity restrictions.  Please also 
follow-up with your primary care physician.

# Hospital Acquired Pneumonia:  Pt recently underwent spinal 
surgery and presented to ___ with post-op fever and septic 
shock.  His CXR showed a new RLL infiltrate and he complains of 
cough, making pneumonia most likely diagnosis.  His U/A was 
clear, surgical site is clean and he does not have any focal 
neuro deficits.  Pt was recently intubated for his procedure, 
and as per ___ notes, it seems that he was over sedated at 
one point requiring narcan, so the possibility of aspiration is 
quite high.  Given that he was only intubated for procedure we 
treated his pneumonia as a hospital acquired pneumonia, rather 
than ventilator acquired pneumonia.  He was initially covered 
with vancomycin and levaquin, and on HD2 he was narrowed to po 
levaquin.  Pt remained afebrile without o2 requirement and his 
leukocytosis resolved.  He was discharged with a 7 day 
antibiotic course for hospital acquired pneumonia.  

#Septic Shock:  secondary to pneumonia as above.  On 
presentation, pt was febrile to ___, with leukocytosis and 
hypotensive to ___ systolic.  He had evidence of end organ 
ischemia with lactate of 2.1 and acute kidney injury with 
elevated BUN and cr.  He was treated with early goal directed 
therapy and initially volume resuscitated with a total of 7 
liters of crystalloid.  Initially his blood pressures did not 
respond adequately, so he was started on phenylephrine and after 
a central line was placed, he was started on norepinephrine.  By 
the time he reached the ___ MICU, his blood pressure was 
normotensive and vasopressors were discontinued.  His CVP 
remained >10 so aggressive volume resuscitation was stopped.  
His lactate came down to 0.9 and his acute kidney injury 
resolved.  Pt remained normotensive for remainder of FICU 
course.  

# s/p Laminectomy - currently no neurological deficits, 
radiculopathy is actually improved since surgery.  Incision site 
was cdi and his dressing was changed as needed.  At time of 
discharge, pt still had staples in place and will need to follow 
up with his neuro-surgeon for post-op check and staple removal.  
He was continued on post-surgical ppx antibiotics 
(dicloxicillin) as prescribed by his surgeon.   

HTN: Pt's antihypertensive medications were held during 
hospitalization due to shock.  At time of discharge, he was 
normotensive.  He was instructed to restart his 
amlodipine/benazapril, but not to restart his triemtarine/HCTZ 
given that he was normotensive at time of discharge.  

SVT: bystolic was held as pt initially in shock.  It was 
restarted at time of discharge.  

Depression/anxiety: continued with venlafaxine and diazepam.  

Transitional: 
- f/u final blood cultures 
- continue for total 7 day course of levaquin 
- f/u with neurosurgeon for staple removal and post op check 
- will need follow up with PCP within one week of discharge

breathing is likely due your mitral valve leaking a little bit

on transesophageal echo that you had 2+ mitral regurgitation

dose of torsemide (50mg daily, which you were taking) and with 
lower doses of your other blood pressure medications to allow 
you a chance to diurese without your blood pressure decreasing 
too much.

Please STOP taking Enalapril

Please CONTINUE torsemide 50mg daily, like you were taking.

than 3 lbs.

Discharge Instructions:
Ms. ___,

You were admitted to ___ for observation following your 
surgery. You did well postoperatively and were discharged home 
once you were eating, on oral medications, walking, and 
completing daily activities as normal. 

Medications: 
You were started on thyroid hormone medication, take as 
prescribed. For pain medication you may take acetaminophen 
(Tylenol)as directed for mild pain. 

Your calcium level is normal at discharge and no calcium 
supplement is needed. However, monitor for symptoms of low 
calcium: If you develop tingling or numbness around your mouth 
or fingertips this may be a sign of a low calcium and you should 
call our office. If you develop severe symptoms, please go to 
emergency room.

Wound care:
You may shower normally. Allow warm soapy water to run over the 
wound, rinse and pat dry gently. There is no need to keep a 
dressing over the wound. Do not apply creams or ointments. Do 
not submerge the wound in a swimming pool or bath until cleared 
at your follow up visit. Do not pull off the steri strip 
tapes--these will fall off by themselves over the next ___ 
weeks.

Diet:
You may resume your regular home diet without restriction. You 
should use stick to foods that do not upset your stomach. You 
may need to start with small meals first and may not feel very 
hungry at first. This will improve over time. You may supplement 
your diet with protein shakes as needed if you do not feel you 
are taking in enough nutrition.

Activity:
You may resume all of your normal home activities, except for 
straining or lifting heavy weight. We recommend you resume 
walking, exercise, bathing, per your normal regimen. 

Warning signs:
You should contact our clinic or return to the ED immediately if 
you experience any of the following signs or symptoms:
Fever above 101.5
Worsening pain
Worsening GI upset, nausea/vomiting, diarrhea
Change in the appearance of your incision, or redness, swelling, 
or change in drainage from your incision
Any other symptoms that concern you

You can contact our clinic at any time with questions or 
concerns. You should be seen in our clinic for follow up 
following your discharge from the hospital. 

Best wishes,
Your ___ Care Team

hospital visits.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo male, PMH of Afib on apixaban, HTN, HLD, presents from 
home with exam concerning for dysarthria, INO on leftward gaze, 
ataxia, and mild left sided weakness found to have acute right 
greater than left pontine stroke on MRI. Given the location of 
his stroke we believe that his stroke was most likely from small 
vessel disease. However, the lack of atherosclerosis on his CTA 
and because of his history of atrial fibrillation, he is at 
increased risk for embolic disease that could have transiently 
occluded bilateral pontine perforators then cleared. CTA showed 
anterior and posterior circulation that showed patent 
vasculature and low atherosclerotic burden. His stroke symptoms 
fluctuated greatly during his admission. His dysarthria was 
intermittent, leftward INO was intermittent but became very 
prominent on discharge, and his left sided weakness increased 
and was especially marked in his leg. At the time of discharge 
he had Left sided ___ IP strength, ___ hamstring strength and 
___ tibialis anterior. He also developed left ptosis, 
intermittent exotropia of his left eye, and was unable to ABduct 
his right eye. He underwent repeat MRI because of these new 
findings on ___ which showed no new stroke but that his old 
stroke was more conspicuous on DWI comparfed to prior MRI on 
___. 

He underwent echocardiogram that showed moderate left and right 
atrial enlargement, no ASD or PFO, and no intracardiac thrombus. 
EF was >55% and there was mild aortic and mitral regurgitation. 
Telemetry showed that the patient was constantly in atrial 
fibrillation and occasionally bradycardic while on a lower dose 
of his home sotalol. Because of the nighttime bradycardia down 
to the ___ at times with 3 second pauses on telemetry, he was 
discharged on this lower dose of sotalol. Higher blood pressures 
were also tolerated while as an inpatient and his quinipril was 
held on discharge. Depending on BP at the rehab, he could resume 
his home dose of quinipril with goal normotension.  

Regarding his risk factors: 
LDL was 101 and HbA1C was 5.7. He was started on Atorvastatin 
40mg daily which he should continue after discharge.

He was continued on his home dose of apixaban which he should 
continue to take as he was prior to hospitalization. We 
cautioned the patient regarding stopping his apixaban in the 
future given this stroke. 

Physical therapy and occupational therapy worked with the 
patient and given his degree of unbalance, he required discharge 
to rehab facility. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
- Sotalol is at half dose of admission medication - Heart rates 
within normal limits.
- Quinipril was not given during admission, this can be 
restarted after getting to rehab with goal of normotension
- Has follow up appointment with Dr. ___ - neurology in 
around ___ months.

Dear Mr. ___, 

You were admitted with feeling unbalanced, double vision, and 
slurred speech. During your admission you also developed left 
sided weakness, left eyelid drooping, and more problems with 
double vision and movement of your eyes. All of these symptoms 
were due to a stroke that you had in your brainstem. You had MRI

vessels in your brain that showed that the vessels were normal 
and open. You continued to be in atrial fibrillation during your 
admission and were continued on your home apixaban which you 
should continue. You also had an echocardiogram that showed 
moderate left and right atrial enlargement, atrial fibrillation, 
no hole connecting the two chambers of the heart, and no clot in 
the chambers of your heart. 

You should continue to take apixaban at your home dose. 

You were started on a cholesterol medication called atorvastatin 
40mg at night to prevent future strokes. Please continue to take 
this and follow up with your primary care provider to help 
adjust dosing as needed.

Brief Hospital Course:
# Hypertensive Urgency/Emergency: Pt presented with 
significantly elevated BPs in 220/120 range after completing a 
clonidine wean.  Pt was essentially asymptomatic on presentation 
but developped a headache in the ED after receiving a nitrate 
and had a head CT that did not show any evidence of ICH.  BP was 
better controlled on arrival to floor but was very labile on day 
2 of admission. She had an episode of vomiting on day 2 most 
likely related to lisinopril intolerance (prior reaction with 
N/V).  Pt was noted to have a significant CK elevation with 
normal MB fraction that trended down in house, it is unclear if 
this elevation was due to demand ischemia vs myopathy. The 
etiology of the hypertensive urgency was thought most likely due 
to recently cessation of clonidine although pt also reported 
taking OTC diet pills & dietary indiscretions.  In keeping with 
her ___ plan, pt was kept off clonidine.  Pt reported many 
medication intolerances including CCBs, but she was switched 
from Toprol to Labetalol 400mg BID and was started on HCTZ 25mg 
which she tolerated well. Otherwise, she was continued on Lasix 
40mg & Benzapril 20mg.  BP was decently well controlled and 
attending felt that the patient was stable for disharge on this 
regimen with plan for follow up with PCP and cardiologist.
.  
#. CAD: Pt has a h/o CAD but we were unable to obtain additional 
records from ___, PCP denied having any recent records. Pt 
denied any chest pain throughout admission but reported some DOE 
on way into ED. EKG from ED had some non-specific changes 
thought most likely due to LVH and hypertensive urgency. Pt was 
noted to have a significantly increased CK at 1361, MB fraction 
was normal. Troponin was mildly elevated at 0.04 most likely due 
to CRI.  CK's trended down to 830 in house and pt was continued 
on ASA 325mg, Labetalol, Benzapril and Lovastatin.  PCP was 
notified about CK elevation and pt will need a follow up CK at 
her next follow up and may need to stop statin if the CK remains 
elevated.
.  
#. Pump/Abn CXR: Pt had a recent echo showing preserved LVEF at 
65% with impaired relaxation, mild AS, mild MR, and mild to 
moderate TR. Pt was noted to have some scattered crackles on 
exam but was sating well on RA & denied any symptoms of volume 
overload. Official CXR reading described findings more 
consistent with an interstitial process than with pulmonary 
edema and recommended a follow up CT.  Pt did not have any 
infectious symptoms and was scheduled to see Pulmonary in follow 
up as an outpatient.  She was continued on Lasix 40mg daily.  
.  
#. Diabetes: Pt described good BS control at home but last 
HgbA1c>10.   Pt was discharged on her home regimen of Insulin 
with glipizide and was encouraged to discuss blood sugar control 
with her PCP in follow up.
.  
# Elevated CK: CK was notably elevated at 1300 on admission, MB 
fraction remained essentially normal and CK trended down to 830 
spontaneously.  Pt did complain of some intermittent lower 
extremity myopathies and has a lower extremity angiogram 
scheduled for next week.  Extremities remained warm and pulses 
were palpable, the lower extremity pain seemed to resolve 
spontaneously.  Etiology of the CK elevation was unclear, it is 
possible that the CK elevation was related to demand ischemia or 
it may have been due to the statin.  Statin induced myositis was 
thought less likely given that it trended down spontaneously 
while continuing the medication.  PCP was notified about this 
elevation and pt will need follow up labs to trend CK. 

# Chronic Pain meds: Pt's pain was well controlled in house on 
her chronic pain regimen of Oxycodone 15mg q8hr prn and pt was 
discharged on this regimen that was clearly outlined by her PCP 
in their ___ contract.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old ___ woman with h/o systolic CHF with EF 
40%, CAD with 2-vessel disease, COPD, afib on coumadin 
presenting with SOB likely due to acute CHF exacerbation. Her 
CXR is interesting for a stable left pleural effusion with only 
mild pulmonary vascular congestion. She was diuresed and 
discharged to rehab. 

ACTIVE ISSUES: 
#  CHF exacerbation: the patient presented with SOB and hypoxia 
most likely due to a CHF exacerbation. The trigger for her 
exacerbation was unclear, but she has been admitted from rehab 
facility for CHF exacerbations multiple times in the past year. 
It was possible that d/t agitation and restlessness she had 
hypertensive episodes that caused flash pulmonary edema. Her 
condition was certainly exacerbated by underlying reactive 
airway disease. She received 80 IV lasix in the ED and continued 
to receive IV lasix on a BID basis for fluid overload. Her urine 
output was monitored with a Foley. She required periodic 2 L NC 
for hypoxia, although she was not requiring O2 by day of 
discharge. During this time, her home torsemide was initially 
stopped. It was recontinued on the day prior to discharge at an 
unchanged dose of 80 mg daily. Her other CHF 
medications--amlodipine, metoprolol tartrate, and 
valsartan--were continued. 

# tremor: patient was noted to have tremor/shaking on exam in 
the ED. She had no other focal neurological deficits, although 
this was difficult to interpret in light of her agitated mental 
state. Her daughter reports has happened in the past when she 
gets diuretics (confirmed by discharge summaries). This could be 
due to electrolyte loss but the association between tremor and 
lasix is unclear at the moment. As she continued to receive 
diuretics, she did not develop worsening of the tremor, and it 
in fact improved such that it was gone by hospital day #2 and 
did not recur. 

# UTI: She had a negative UA on admission, although she has h/o 
severe UTI in the past. After day #3 with the Foley in place, 
turbid and foul-smelling urine was noted, prompting a repeat UA 
that showed 12 WBCs and bacteria. She was started on empiric 
5-day course of PO Cipro for UTI, with ucx pending at time of 
discharge. 

#  atrial fibrillation: the patient's home dose of warfarin was 
decreased to 3 on hospital day #1, and continued at this dose 
given supratherapeutic INR, although she missed a dose on ___ 
due to pharmacy withholding the dose for an INR of 4.7. She was 
discharged with a changed dose of 2 mg warfarin daily. She was 
continued on her home dose of metoprolol.  

CHRONIC ISSUES: 

# dementia: patient has h/o dementia and agitated delirium which 
is usual for her in the setting of hospitalizations where she is 
exposed to new people and environments. During her stay, she was 
more agitated for the first couple of days, and at one point was 
throwing things at her nurses. ___ was intermittently agitated, 
and completely dis-oriented to place, time, and location which 
is her known norm. She did not require olanzapine (which in the 
past has not been successful). She was continued on her home 
12.5 mg quetiapine and 25 mg tramadol qhs. Beginning on ___, 
she refused IV access and pulled out her IVs so could not be 
given IV meds. She had to be persuaded by ___ staff 
to allow the phlebotomist to draw her blood. She had to be 
coaxed to take her PO medications with chocolate ice cream, 
which she enjoys. 

#  CAD: two-vessel disease as seen on cath in ___. She was 
continued on her home 81 mg ASA, metoprolol, atorvastatin 10 mg 
  
#  HTN: she was continued on home metoprolol 50 mg TID, imdur 90 
mg

SOB

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was transferred to ___ for observation and treatment 
of her right upper quadrant pain.  Her pancreatic enzymes were 
normal.  Repeat RUQ ultrasound was consistent with gallstones 
without signs of infection or CBD stone.  She continued however 
to have nausea/vomiting and poor pain control.  Repeat labs 
confirmed progression to pancreatitis.  She was taken to labor 
and delivery for repeat c-section on hospital day 2. Her 
delivery at 37 weeks 2 days EGA was uncomplicated. 
Post-operatively, she had significant pain medication 
requirements and thus was placed on a dilaudid PCA.

Post-operatively, the gastroenterology team was consulted, who 
recommended ERCP. On hospital day 3, post-partum day 1, she 
underwent an ERCP with spincterotomy under general anesthesia, 
in which sludge was extracted from the biliary tract. There were 
no stones in the biliary tract. Following her ERCP, her pain was 
managed with a dilaudid PCA and she remained NPO. She was 
started on Ciprofloxacin 400mg for a 5 day course, per GI 
recommendations. On hospital day 4, post-partum day 2, she was 
transitioned to oral pain medications and her diet was advanced. 
By hospital day 5, post-partum day 3, she was tolerating a 
regular diet. Her LFTs began trending down following her ERCP.
The patient was discharged in good condition, with plan to 
follow-up for an outpatient cholecystectomy. Her post-partum 
course was otherwise uncomplicated.

Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with a PMH significant only for 
nephrolithiasis. The patient presented to the emergency 
department with complaints of abdominal pain. Imaging was 
completed and CT demonstrated 4.6x4.0cm phlegmon with adjacent 
abscesses. Therefore, the Acute Care Surgery team was consulted 
for further evaluation and management. He was subsequently taken 
to the operating room and underwent exploratory laparotomy with 
extended right colectomy on ___. (Please see operative 
report for details of this procedure). He tolerated the 
procedure well, was extubated upon completion, and was taken to 
the PACU for recovery after which he was transferred to the 
floor in stable condition.

Beginning on POD1, the patient was started on a clear liquid 
diet and his pain was well controlled on oral pain medication. 
However, he did not have return of bowel function until POD5 
when he began to have flatus. His diet was then progressively 
advanced until he was tolerating a regular diet. During this 
hospitalization, the patient voided without difficulty and 
ambulated early and frequently. He was adherent with respiratory 
toilet and incentive spirometry and actively participated in the 
plan of care. The patient received subcutaneous heparin and 
venodyne boots were used during this stay.

At the time of discharge on ___, the patient was doing well. 
He was afebrile and his vital signs were stable. The patient was 
discharged home without services. Discharge teaching was 
completed and follow-up instructions were reviewed with reported 
understanding and agreement.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ for 
evaluation of abdominal pain. A cat scan was competed which 
found an area of inflammation in your abdomen with adjacent 
abscesses. Therefore, you were taken to the operating room and 
underwent removal of a portion of your colon. You are recovering 
well and are now ready for discharge. Please follow the 
instructions below to continue your recovery:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. 
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
