Brief Hospital Course:
___ woman with dementia, DMII, HTN, CVA x2 (on plavix 
and coumadin), and CRI who was transferred from ___ 
___ yesterday for concern of sepsis ___ cholangitis.

# Septic Shock
She underwent a CT abdomen/pelvis, which revealed extensive 
fecal loading but no evidence of biliary pathology. She was 
admitted to the MICU given her hypotension (SBP 70-80s). Stool 
disimpaction was performed aggressively multiple times with 
retrieval of a large amount of stool, which was trace guaiac 
positive. However, despite this, her lactate continued to trend 
up (from 3.7 to 5.8) and she remained hypotensive despite 
generous fluid resuscitation. She had received 4L prior to her 
MICU admission and received a further 3L while in the ICU but 
was still requiring levophed. She received empiric vanc/zosyn, 
as well as IV flagyl for coverage of c diff empirically. The ACS 
service was consulted for consideration of ischemic colitis as 
potential source of rising lactate and persistent hypotension. 
Her exam was concerning for abdominal distension and apparent 
discomfort with abdominal palpation, and CT was suggestive of 
possible ischemic colitis related to massive dilaion of bowel 
with stool. They thought her sepsis was likely due to a urinary 
source rather than ischemic bowel, and did not think surgical 
intervention was indicated. Overnight, her lactate continued 
trend up with increasing pressor requirements. Urine and blood 
cultures remained negative. Her family decided to make her CMO 
and she expired shortly after.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was a ___ transferred from OSH to the ACS service 
due to being hemodinamically stable from a liver laceration of 
unknown etiology. Upon report from the OSH surgeon, the patient 
was found down, altered, and hypotensive at home and rushed to 
the hospital by EMT. Upon evaluation the patient was taken 
emergently to the operating room where an exploratory laparotomy 
was performed. Upon entering the abdomen a laceration over the 
dome of the liver was seen and hemostasis was attempted. Due to 
not being able to control the bleeding, packing's where placed 
over and under the liver, the abdomen was temporarily closed 
with a ioban dressing and the patient was transferred to ___ 
for further care. Upon arrival the patient was hypotensive, on 
pressors and with a wbc of 48.3. The patient blood lost was 
sustained by Massive transfusion protocol. The abdominal 
dressing was opened and a wound vac suction was placed from 
which he was losing frank blood. During his stay in the ICU 
hemodynamic were maintain with multiple pressors medications, 
blood products and crystalloids. All his electrolytes where 
tried to be corrected during this time. The patient also 
received TXA for suspected coagulopathy. Due to continued 
deterioration of his symptoms, a family meeting was arranged and 
the decision of the family was to make him CMO. The patient 
expired shortly afterwards.

General Instructions

•Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
•Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
•Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
•Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, or 
Ibuprofen etc. 
•You were taking Aspirin prior to your injury, you may safely 
resume taking this on ___.
 

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

•New onset of tremors or seizures.
•Any confusion, lethargy or change in mental status. 
•Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
•Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
•New onset of the loss of function, or decrease of function on 
one whole side of your body.

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient went into PEA arrest with ROSC at rehab, upon arrival to 
___ she was hypotensive and required levophed gtt to maintain 
MAP>60. Likely cause of cardiac arrest was thought to be 
hypoxemia as patient was found to be satting in the ___ on 
rehab. It was determined that there was no need to undergo 
cooling protocol as patient's mental status was at baseline. 
Shock was determined to be septic secondary to ongoing infection 
at her cervical spine, as incision site was noted to be draining 
purulent fluid. She was started broadly on vanc/cefepime/flagyl. 


Patient was noted to have distended abdomen on exam. Given 
history of hep B cirrhosis she underwent diagnostic paracentesis 
due to concern for SBP in the setting of septic shock. 
Peritoneal fluid grew yeast and she was started on micafungin 
for fungal peritonitis.

Patient also presented with acute on chronic hypoxemic 
respiratory failure requiring CMV. CXR showed a large left 
pleural effusion. It was thought that she may have had a 
seizure, causing aspiration and thus hypoxemia. ___ was 
obtained given mild c/f PE and ruled out DVT. She was also 
continued on home phenytoin, keppra and lacosamide.  

On hospital day 3 at 1550 patient was becoming increasingly 
bradycardic. She received atropine 0.5mg x1 without effect. At 
1600 she was noted to be apneic. Family was notified and 
requested that patient be kept alive until her husband arrived 
on ___ night. However it was determined that CPR was not 
indicated as discussed on rounds in the morning. At 1605 she 
went into asystole. Her chest was auscultated for 1 minute 
without cardiac or breath sounds with the vent turned off. Her 
pupils were fixed and dilated. She was pronounced at 1606.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is an ___ with PMHx of HTN, prostate Ca ___ yrs 
ago), recent h/o of GI bleed (___) drove himself to the ED 
after having a ___ minute episode of wording finding difficultly 
after giving a 3 hour lecture at ___ where he teaches 
___. It seems he has had 2 episodes of word finding 
difficulty in the last several months. Differential includes 
TIAs, Strokes, Amyloid Angiopathy, Seizures, Migraines. On exam, 
he has a sixth nerve palsy which is likely chronic since he 
doesn't complain of double vision. Given the acute onset, short 
duration of his symptoms with return to baseline, evidence of 
small vessel ischemic disease on MR and recent history of 
elevated blood pressures, TIA is the likely cause of his 
symptoms. CT and MR did not show signs of intracranial bleeding, 
mass effect, ischemia or large vessel stenosis. A seizure was 
also considered as a possible cause of his symptoms, however no 
seizure activity or epileptiform discharges were seen on EEG. 
Amyloid angiopathy is also a potential cause of his symptoms, 
though there is no evidence of microbleeds on imaging. Lastly, 
his symptoms could also be due to migraines, however he has no 
history of migraines or chronic headaches. 

Final diagnosis: TIA

The patient presented to Emergency Department on ___. Pt was 
evaluated by upon arrival to ED.  Given findings and concern for 
acute ischemia, the patient was taken for CT of abdomen and 
pelvis which demonstrated "Marked wall thickening of distal 
transverse colon and descending colon with adjacent fat 
stranding consistent with
colitis. No free air or free fluid in abdomen or pelvis. No 
fluid
collections." The patient was then transferred to the ward for 
observation, colonoscopy, serial abdominal exams, empiric 
antibiotics (Zosyn).
 
Neuro: The patient was alert and oriented throughout 
hospitalization; optimal pain control was ultimately achieved 
with oral vicodin which patient takes at home. 
CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. 
GI/GU/FEN: The patient was initially kept NPO. On HD2 patient 
received bowel prep and went of flexible sigmoidoscopy with 
biopsy by gastroenterology.  Findings werw patchy
erythema and scattered ulcers considered not classic for 
ischemic colitis. Biopsies confirmed mild ischemic colitis with 
chronic changes. Lact and WBC downtrended from 2.9--> 1.6 and 
18-->16, respectively and the patient's symptoms gradually 
improved. Diet was advanced sequentially to a Regular diet, 
which was well tolerated on HD 3. Patient's intake and output 
were closely monitored.
ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection, of which there were none. Stool was sent for cultures 
and O&P which resulted negative, no campylobacter, salmonella, 
shigella, or e. coli O157:H7. CMV PCR, BCx and UCx also were 
negative.
HEME: The patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs 
of bleeding. The patient continued to have small amounts of 
bloody BMs through HD2. Her H&H remained stable thereafter.
Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and ___ 
dyne boots were used during this stay and was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.  Patient was discharged with 
PO augmentin and instructions to follow-up in ___ clinic.

Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or

bowel movement.

urine, or experience a discharge.

getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.

you.
Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ ___ male with a history of Crohn's with a history 
of partial colectomy and subsequent development of incisional 
hernia, s/p Rives Stoppa repair on ___ presented to the 
___ ED on ___ with 2 days of abdominal pain and 1 day of 
nausea and emesis. The patient had an uncomplicated 
post-operative course and was discharged on POD#3.

Upon evaluation, there was concern for a small bowel 
obstruction. CT imaging revealed signs of a potential 
mid-jejunal obstruction. He had an NG tube placed and was 
admitted for IVF and monitoring.

On ___, it was noted that his pain was increasing and not 
adequately controlled by the IV dilaudid. His NGT was advanced 
to the appropriate depth and he had up to 750 cc suctioned over 
the day with some relief of his discomfort.

On hospital day 5, a PICC line was placed by the IV team and 
nutrition consulted regarding TPN. He was started on TPN on 
___ and IVF was reduced to maintenance level. 

On hospital 6 and ___, he passed flatus and was having bowel 
movements. His JP drain was removed due to consistently low 
output as was the NG tube. His diet was advanced to sips. Early 
morning of hospital day 8, he vomited and NG tube was replaced 
with about 100 cc of output. He developed tachycardia to the 
120s, a fever of 101.4, and WBC count from 12 to 20.6. He was 
evaluated and it was determined that he should undergo a CT 
Abdomen/Pelvis with both IV and PO contrast to look for fluid 
collections, abscesses around the surgical site, or a 
re-obstruction of the intestines. The study revealed a high 
grade SBO with abnormal mucosal hyperenhancement of the 
neoterminal ileum and cecum, suggestive of active Crohn's 
disease; however, this finding was similar to a past study done 
in ___. Gastroenterology was consulted and recommended treating 
the SBO and an outpatient colonoscopy, for which he is due. For 
the time, no specialized treatment or further diagnostic testing 
would be useful over a colonoscopy when able. 

He was taken to the OR on hospital day 10 for exploratory 
laparotomy with lysis of adhesions. Post-operatively, he had his 
pain managed acutely via an epidural by the Acute Pain Service. 
It was removed on POD5 (hospital day 15) as well as the foley. 
He was transitioned to IV pain medication and had return of 
bowel function.

His diet was advanced as tolerated to a regular diet with 
continuous bowel function and pain controlled. His was 
discharged home on HOD ___ in stable condition.

Mr. ___, it was a pleasure taking care of you at ___.

You were admitted to the hospital due to a bowel obstruction, 
conservative management was attempted with nasogastric tube

discharge to home with the following instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.

or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.

bowel movement.

urine, or experience a discharge.

within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.

any new medications as prescribed.

per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were hospitalized due to symptoms of headache, nausea and 
vomiting resulting from an ACUTE INTRACEREBRAL HEMORRHAGE, a 
condition where a blood vessel bleeds into a part of your brain. 
The brain is the part of your body that controls and directs all 
the other parts of your body, so bleeding into the brain can 
affect the way your body functions and cause the symptoms you 
experienced.

 We believe the bleeding was most likely caused by elevated 
blood pressure in combination with having your blood thinned 
while on Coumadin. Moving forward, achieving and maintaining 
good control of your blood pressure is of utmost importance. We 
are increasing your blood pressure medications to help control 
your blood pressure moving forward. Your PCP can follow up on 
your blood pressure and may make further adjustments in the 
future.

Although you were on Coumadin to prevent blood clots that could 
cause stroke due to your atrial fibrillation, we feel the risk 
of bleeding again in the future outweighs the risk of having 
blood clots.

 We are changing your medications as follows: 

 STOP taking Warfarin. 
 INCREASE your dose of Losartan from 25mg daily to 100mg daily.
 START HCTZ
 INCREASE metoprolol dosage

 Please take your other medications as prescribed.  

 Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician 

as listed below.  

 If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:  

 - Sudden partial or complete loss of vision  
 - Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth  
 - Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you  
 - Sudden weakness of one side of the body  
 - Sudden drooping of one side of the face  
 - Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body  

 Sincerely,  

 Your ___ Neurology Team

Brief Hospital Course:
___ man with H/O methamphetamine induced dilated 
cardiomyopathy (LVEF 35% in ___ hepatitis C, HIV (history of 
non-compliance with HAART), polysubstance abuse, DVT on Coumadin 
(___) which was discontinued due to noncompliance in ___ who presents as planned direct admission arranged by 
cardiology clinic with orthostasis, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, 
and acute renal failure (baseline cr=0.9).

Acute Renal Failure:
Patient had recent lab values consistent with acute renal 
failure. His blood urea nitrogen was 70 and creatinine was 2.3, 
suggestive of a prerenal etiology for his acute renal failure. 
Further supporting this diagnosis was the fact that the patient 
had recently been taking torsemide and having his dose decreased 
secondary to polyuria over the past month. Upon arrival to the 
floor, the patient had not taken any of his medications 
prescribed for heart failure with the exception of metoprolol. 
In the absence of torsemide, the patient's serum transaminases 
and serum creatinine slightly decreased. The patient was given a 
500 mL bolus of normal saline and he ate a regular meal for 
dinner without fluid restrictions. By withholding the loop 
diuretic and repleting intravascular volume, his sodium, 
potassium, and creatinine normalized the following day. As a 
result, all of the patient's medications with the exception of 
metoprolol were held. Given that the patient has systolic heart 
failure, he will need restarted on these medications. It is 
likely that his medication regimen was escalated slightly too 
aggressively and needs to retitrated.  
- The patient has follow-up labs which will be drawn in 2 days, 
and he has an appointment with his primary care physician who 
can review the laboratory values and reassess the patient’s 
medications.
- The patient also has an appointment with his out patient 
cardiologist in 6 days. During that visit, Dr. ___  ___ 
re-titrate the patient’s medications for optimal cardiac 
secondary and primary prevention.

Elevated AST/ALT:  
- Patient presented with market elevations in his serum 
transaminases. Our differential for this diagnosis was broad. 
Given his past history of DVT, there was a concern of hepatic 
venous thrombosis. This was excluded by his right upper quadrant 
Doppler ultrasound study. Congestive hepatopathy is also an 
unlikely diagnosis given that the patient was clinically 
euvolaemic or even hypovolemic upon presentation. A viral 
etiology for his liver enzyme abnormalities could not be ruled 
out given the patient's HIV and hepatitis C. Hepatology was 
consulted and they felt like the most likely cause of his 
elevated liver enzymes was due to hypoperfusion. Once the 
patient was given back volume, his liver enzymes trended down 
slightly (but were still markedly elevated). His primary care 
physician ___ check his LFTs on ___ and should abnormalities 
still persist then outpatient referral to a hepatologist may be 
warranted.
Recommendations per hepatology consult:
1. Continue to monitor LFTs until recovery to baseline.
2. F/u HCV viral load q 6 months 
3. Maintain adequate blood pressure and avoid systemic arterial 
hypotension
4. OK to do trial of Atripla once his LFTs normalize.

Chronic left ventricular systolic heart failure.
Echocardiogram performed the day prior to admission showed LVEF 
35%-40%. There was mild to moderate global left ventricular 
hypokinesis with normal cavity size. Mildly dilated right 
ventricular cavity with mild free wall hypokinesis. Compared 
with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, the left 
ventricular cavity is less dilated, the global function is 
improved, and the degree of mitral regurgitation is decreased. 
He was continued on his beta-blocker.

In summary: the patient presented to ___ 3 generally feeling 
well. He has been able to walk his dogs several miles a day 
without chest pain or shortness of breath. His appetite was good 
and the patient was in good spirits during his hospitalization.

watery, it may be more consistent with a small-bowel issue. Low 
CD4 puts her at increased risk for cryptosporidium, MAC, 
isospora, microsporidium, CMV and giardia, however, her diarrhea 
improved and her fevers resolved. She has had no recent HAART 
medication changes. Also, given low CD4, inflitrative diseases 
such as Kaposi and lymphoma should remain on the ddx, though 
less likely, given acuity. Additionally she has known multiple 
colonic diverticuli and she may have developed diverticulitis, 
however she had no further fevers during this hospitalization 
and her abdominal exam was benign and inconsistent with 
diverticulitis. Stool studies were negative to date; blood 
culture was also negative to date and we discontinued empiric 
cipro/flagyl per ID recommendations on consultation, given that 
her diarrhea and fevers resolved and clinically she looked so 
well.  She was discharged with close ID follow-up.
 
#HIV/AIDS: CD4 of 24 on ___ we continued darunavin stribild, 
as well as azithromycin and atovaquone ppx given CD4 count. 

___: mild Cr elevation likely in the setting of poor po intake 
a fluid lossess from diarrhea is s/p IVF In ED. Cr initially 
improved with IVF, however, then plateaued at a value of 1.4 
which was above her baseline of 0.8. Urine lytes yielded a FeNa 
of 2.2%, with granular casts on her urine sediment,  suggestive 
of ATN in the setting of dehydration. She had good urine output 
and was discharged with outpatient labs to be done the week 
following didscharge for a creatinine check.
  
# Transaminitis: Improved. This was a new problem for her, ratio 
of elevation is most consistent with alcholic hepatocellular 
damage, however, she denies etoh. Could also be from infectious 
illness which is being worked up as above. In an immune 
suppressed patient with diarrhea and elevated transaminases and 
Alkphos, it is improtant to consider MAC, however, given her 
clinical picture, this was thought to be less likely.  
 
# Anemia: normocytic anemia with normal RDW that appears to be 
at baseline since ___, likely secondary to chronic disease. 
Tbili normal and no evidence of schistocytes, so hemolysis from 
an infectious process less likely. This remained stable 
throughout her admission.
  
# Monocytosis: Resolved. not uncommon in the setting of 
inflammatory states and AI conditions and corticosteroid 
exposure. Also known to accompany conditions associated with 
neutropenia, thought to be compensatory. Infectiuons may also be 
associated with moncytosis. Monocytosis may also be seen in 
certain malignancies, such as lymphomas.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,  

It was a pleasure caring for you at ___.  

WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL?  
- You were in the hospital because you had shortness of breath 
and you were found to have blood clots in the your legs and 
blood clots in your lungs.

WHAT HAPPENED TO ME IN THE HOSPITAL?  
- Your blood clots were treated with a blood thinning 
medications. Because the clots got bigger, the medication was 
changed from warfarin and heparin to Lovenox shots
- You had dizziness, fast heart rates, low blood pressure with 
standing which improved overtime and were thought to be related 
to the blood clots
- You received medication for constipation
- You had difficulty passing urine and had a catheter placed
- You had a fever that was thought to be due to your blood clots
- You were seen by our inpatient psychiatry team who recommended 
medications for anxiety

WHAT SHOULD I DO AFTER I LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?  
- Continue to take all your medicines and keep your 
appointments.
- Inject the lovenox blood thinner medication every morning and 
every night  
- Make sure to take in enough fluids throughout the day to 
prevent your blood pressure from getting too low
- Follow the post-operative instructions below
- Consider enrolling in a partial psychiatric program to work on 
coping skills
- Please use compression stockings on your legs to minimize 
swelling and improve circulation

We wish you the best!  

Sincerely,  
Your ___ Team  

Surgery:

•Do not apply any lotions or creams to the surgical site. 
•Please avoid swimming for two weeks after staple removal.
•Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity:
•We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
•You may take leisurely walks and slowly increase your activity 
at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
•No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
•No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 

Medications: 
•You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
•It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain 
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. 
Pain medications can cause constipation. 

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
•Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
•Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
•New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.

constipation and constipation related to narcotic pain

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with stage IV pancreatic cancer now causing gastric oulet 
obstruction s/p NG tube placement for decompression with no 
surgical options for obstruction management.  His course was 
complicated by hypotension that was managed with IVF boluses.    


# Gastric outlet obstruction: Mr. ___ presented with signs and 
symptoms of severe obstruction likely secondary to his 
progressive pancreatic cancer.  On presentation to the ICU, his 
abdominal pain appeared to have resolved now that he is s/p NG 
tube placement. NG tube was kept in place until pt self removed. 
He was seen by palliative care and started on octreotide however 
he still had abdominal pain, distension and emesis. Surgery was 
consulted and had no interventions to offer. GI was consulted 
and was able to place a duodenal stent across the stricture. 
After the procedure pt was able to tolerate a low residue diet 
without emesis. He was seen by nutrition for education on this 
diet.

# Metabolic Alkalosis: Patient presented with severe contraction 
alkalosis. Likely in the setting of vomitting secondary to 
obstruction. Resolved with IVF.  

# Elevated lactate: Lactate was 3.3 on admission, improved to 
2.9 with IVF.  Etiology was likely multifactorial. Possibly due 
to hypoprofusion in setting of poor PO intake and hypotension. 
Resolved with hydration

# Acute Kidney Injury: Profound increase in creatinine.  His 
poor PO intake and vomitting may be contributing to a prerenal 
picture. Urine output was stable.  His creatine improved from 
4.6 to 3.8 with IVF.  After procedure he was able to maintain 
his own hydration with IVF and Cr decreased to 1.2 which is is 
baseline.
 
# Coagulopathy: All coagulation factors were elevated, this was 
due to nutritional deficits as well as progression of pancreatic 
disease to liver. His INR improved with IV vitamin K which was 
given prior to GI procedure.   

# GOC:  Spoke with patient's wife he reports that Mr. ___ was 
on hospice and has decided to defer any further treatment of his 
pancreatic cancer.  Both she and Mr. ___ would like him to 
return home they were comfortable with this after his clinical 
improvement.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo woman with history of mixed connective 
tissue disease and rheumatoid arthritis,(on prednisone and 
leflunomide) who presented with acute onset low back and right 
buttock radicular pain.  
.  
# Back/Buttock pain: 
The patient presented with right lower back pain radiating to 
the groin and pelvis. At the time of presentation there was no 
numbness, weakness or incontinence that would suggest cauda 
equina syndrome, and rectal tone was reported to be normal.  She 
went on to develop numbness of the right labia.  An MRI was 
obtained to evaluate for possible cord compression.  The imaging 
revealed an 8mm Tarlov cyst compressing the S2 nerve root, 
consistent with the patient's distribution of pain and numbness. 

.
Neurology and Neurosurgery consults were obtained, both of whom 
initially recommended conservative management for pain control.  
Pain management declined to perform an S2 nerve block secondary 
to the risk of infection in an immunosuppressed individual.  The 
patient's symptoms did not improve with this conservative 
approach and her pain continued to worse.  The patient underwent 
a S1-S2 bilateral laminectomy on ___.  She tolerated the 
procedure well with no immediate complications.  She continued 
to have some pain following her operation, but it was much 
improved.  She was able to ambulate well with the physical 
therapist prior to discharge.
.  
# Mixed connective tissue disease/rheumatoid arthritis:  
The patient was evaluated by the rheumatologists who recommended 
continuing her home medications: prednisone and leflunomide.  
They felt her rheumatological diseases were stable and not 
contributing to her current symptoms. 
.  
# Recurrent osteomyelitis: 
The patient recently finished IV antibiotic course for her 
recurrent osteomyelitis and is currently on PO doxycycline for 
suppression therapy, which was continued during this 
hospitalization.  
.  
Chronic Medical Problems
# Hypertension: Continued home meds, well controlled. 
# Asthma: Exercise-induced, patient reports symptoms stable.  A 
PRN albuterol inharler was provided but was not used.   
# Tobacco use: Pt was provided with a nicotine patch and 
lozenges if she requested.
# GERD: Continued home dose pantoprazole

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms ___,

You were recently hospitalized at the ___ 
___ for chest pain.  We performed a few tests to look 
at the heart and determine if this was the source of your pain.  
We looked at the electrical circuitry of the heart with an 
electrocardiogram, which was normal!  We collected samples of 
your blood to look for a specific protein, known as troponin, 
that gets released when the heart is damaged.  This was normal!  
We then performed a cardiac catheterization, which looks at the 
vessels surrounding the heart.  This was also normal!  
Fortunately, this means that your chest pain is not due to heart 
disease.

We suggest that you follow up with your primary care provider 
and cardiologist regarding these results.  You have an 
appointment on ___ with Dr. ___ at 3pm.

You should also follow up with your primary care provider, and 
we are in the process of arranging an appointment with them.  If 
you do not hear from them within the next week, please call 
their office.

It was a pleasure taking care of you.
Your ___ cardiology team

Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male with a past medical history of HTN, 
DM, CAD, obesity, OSA who presented to the ED with chest pain 
c/f ACS s/p cardiac catherization with no stentable disease.  

# NSTEMI: Patient has multiple risk factors for ACS. Patient had 
troponins that had peaked during stay, and was initially placed 
on maximal medical therapy and heparin gtt. Patient underwent 
cardiac catheterization which then showed 90% obstructing lesion 
in the acute RCA marginal branch, and 60-70% circumflex lesion, 
however unable to intervene with any stenting. Therefore, it was 
proposed that patient should optimize medical management and was 
continued on heparin gtt for 48 hours. Patient's blood pressure 
regimen was better optimized and was stable for discharge. We 
continued daily aspirin 81, changed atorvastatin 80 mg qhs to 
rosuvastatin 40 qhs, carvedilol 12.5 mg PO/NG BID. Patient will 
stay on  Plavix for ___ year at 75 mg/day. ECHO showed a preserved 
EF >55%.

insulin sliding scale while inpatient.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old man with a history of St. ___ AVR after two 
previous valve replacements secondary to bicuspid aortic valve 
was admitted for evaluation of GI bleed while on coumadin.    
.  
# GI bleed:   Found to be secondary to gastritis based on EGD 
results of erythema and erosion of the mucosa in the antrum and 
stomach body.  Colonoscopy showed no abnormalities.  GI was 
consulted during the admission.  They recommended H pylori 
testing, which was negative, and capsule endoscopy to be 
completed as an outpatient for complete work up of GI bleed.  
Patient instructed to schedule capsule endoscopy as outpatient.  
Patient was continued on twice a day IV pantoprazole while 
inpatient and switched to oral regimen prior to discharge.   
Active type and screen completed as well as two large bore iv's 
placed on admission.  Trended patient's hematocrit daily.  
Baseline Hct was difficult to determine as has fluctuated 
dramatically during previous hospitalizations, however remained 
stable through this hospitalization.  Iron studies, B12 and 
folate all within normal limits.  The patient was on iron 
therapy prior to admission, held per GI for colonoscopy ease.  
The patient was restarted on iron prior to discharge.  
Haptoglobin was found to be less than 20 on three separate 
occasions.  This finding points towards hemolysis of unclear 
etiology, however unknown significance in the setting of 
splenectomy.  The patient was restarted on heparin drip 
initially then coumadin when patient no longer reported melena 
or hematochezia.  We held the patient's aspirin during the 
hospitalization.  As discussed further below, the patient should 
have a discussion with his primary care physician as to when to 
restart aspirin therapy.  Propranolol was also held initially 
given the GI bleed, but restarted at home dose prior to 
discharge.  
.
# Right-rib and abdominal pain s/p traumatic injury of fall:  We 
had a low level of concern for intra-abdominal/subcapsular liver 
injury with fall in setting of clinical appearance.  The 
patient's liver function tests were only mildly elevated and the 
history of alcohol use was definitely considered as the 
etiology.  CT scan of the chest, abdomen and pelvis did not show 
any sign of concerning retroperitoneal process, see discussion 
of CT findings below.  Pain most likely result of 
musculoskeletal discomfort.  Pain resolved with tylenol only.  
Patient asymptomatic prior to discharge. 
.  
# CORONARIES:  Recent cardiac cath in ___ showed left dominant 
system revealed 
nonobstructive coronary disease, with no disease in the ___, 
minimal disease in the LAD, the LCX was dominant and had a long 
50% OM1 lesion and LPDA with minimal disease and the RCA with 
diffuse disease.  No active ischemia evident on admission or 
during hospitalization.  One set of cardiac enzymes negative.  
As above, aspirin was held during the hospitalization given the 
recent GI bleed.  Given the patient has significant 
non-obstructive coronary artery disease, the patient should be 
restarted on aspirin therapy in the future.  Encouraged the 
patient to discuss this with his primary care doctor on follow 
up.  As above, initially held propranolol, however restarted 
during hospitalization.  The patient reported he was taking 
propranolol only once daily, we restarted on TID regimen and 
discharged the patient home with this regimen.  We also continue 
the patient's home statin regimen.  
.  
# PUMP: The patient has a EF reduced by recent intra-operative 
TEE during most recent aortic valve replacement.  The patient 
was monitored for signs of congestive heart failure and volume 
overload.  The patient remained euvolemic during the 
hospitalization and did not require diuretic therapy.  We 
continued the propanolol as above.   
.  
# RHYTHM: The patient has a history of sinus tachycardia, 
however remained in normal sinus rhythm during hospitalization.  
He was monitored continuously on telemetry.  The patient was 
continued on propranolol as above.
.  
# Mechanical AVR:  The patient has a history of congenital 
bicuspid aortic valve, s/p three valve replacements.  Most 
recent valve is a St. ___ valve.  The patient was therapeutic 
with regards to his coumadin dosing on admission, however 
coumadin held for GI bleed.  Heparin drip was initiated, then 
coumadin added when procedures completed.  The patient was 
initially loaded with coumadin at a dose of 10mg per day, thus 
was bridged for one day while INR therapeutic on heparin drip 
prior to discontinuing the heparin.  The patient was discharged 
on his home dose of coumadin 4mg every day with the instruction 
to follow up with his ___ clinic for frequent checks.  We 
monitored his INR daily while inpatient.  Patient was 
therapeutic for two days prior to discharge.
.  
# Abdominal lymphadenopathy:  Patient had known abdominal 
lymphadenopathy in the setting of traumatic splenectomy.  The 
patient has been followed by Dr. ___ the lymphadenopathy. 
 During his hospitalization a CT Abd Pelvis was completed for 
evaluation of flank pain and to monitor progression of 
lymphadenopathy.  A renal mass was noted on the CT scan.  
Urology, Dr. ___, was consulted for further evaluation of 
possible urothelial malignancy.  While the patient was off 
coumadin, a cystoscopy was performed.  The mass noted on CT scan 
was noted on cystoscopy to be a prominent papilla of the renal 
parenchyma.  There was no evidence of urothelial malignancy on 
the cystoscopy or by cytology of the bladder washings.  The 
patient did experience hematuria following the cystoscopy.  This 
was as suspected as the patient although was not on coumadin, 
was on heparin drip at the time of the procedure.  The patient 
had no symptoms of dysuria, urgency, hesitancy or failure to 
complete voiding during the time of hematuria.  The patient was 
instructed to follow up with Dr. ___ week of discharge.  

.
# Depression: Stable on admission.  Continued home regimen of 
lexapro throughout hospital course.  
.  
# EtOH abuse: Per patient's history, however alcohol level on 
admission was zero.  We monitored the patient for signs of 
withdrawal and maintained the patient on a CIWA scale, given his 
history of post-op delirium, however the patient did not require 
the use of any benzodiazepines.  The patient was started on 
thiamine and folic acid on admission. This regimen was continued 
throughout the hospitalization.
.  
FEN: The patient was maintained on a heart healthy, regular 
diet.  Repleted electrolytes as needed.
.  
ACCESS: two large bore peripheral IV's
.  
PROPHYLAXIS:  initially therapeutic on coumadin, then heparin 
drip.
.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ is an ___ lady woman with a history of CVA, Afib 
(on Warfarin), hypothyroidism, and HTN who presented with 3 days 
of fever, dysuria, and suprapubic pain and was found to have a 
UTI.  Her symptoms resolved with antibiotics and she was 
discharged home.

ACTIVE ISSUES

#. UTI: E.coli, sensitive to Bactrim.
She was found to have positive UA and urine cultures positive 
for E.coli, sensitive to Bactrim.  She had been treated with IV 
Ceftriaxone but when culture data returned she was discharged 
home to complete a 10 day course of antibiotics.  Bactrim will 
end ___.

#. Supratherapeutic INR: now resolved.
The pt came in with INR of 3.3. Her warfarin was held for one 
day and restarted again at 1mg. On her third day of 
hospitalization we increased it to 2mg. She takes 3mg daily as 
outpatient. Her PCP manages her ___ she was advised to 
follow-up there for an INR check 2 days after discharge.

#. Delirium: resolving.
Per family, she was slightly more confused than baseline, which 
was attributed to her infection and also to being in an 
unfamiliar environment.  She was oriented x place (hospital in 
the ___) but she did not know the date - per family, this is 
baseline.  By the time of discharge, family said that she was at 
baseline.  She was evaluated by ___ who felt she was stable to go 
home with 24H supervision by her family for a few days.

#. Hyponatremia: resolved, likely hypovolemic hyponatremia.
She was found to have low sodium on admission which responded 
promptly to IV fluids. Per her daughter, she was not taking in 
many fluids prior to admission, and we believe the diagnoses was 
hypovolemic hyponatremia.  Resolved by discharge.

INACTIVE ISSUES

#. Back pain: chronic issue.
The patient complained of back pain when lying down in bed. Her 
daughter attributes this to previous spinal compression 
fractures secondary to osteoporosis. We treated her pain with 
tylenol, and she improved. 

#. HTN: stable.
Documented history of HTN, on atenolol 100mg po daily as 
outpatient. We continued her regimen in the hospital. Her blood 
pressure readings were reasonable and no adjustment of her 
medications was needed.

#. Afib: on Warfarin.
Team adjusted warfarin dose as described above. Her condition 
remained stable.

#. Hypothyroidism: stable.
Her TSH was measured and found to be normal. We did not adjust 
her levothyroxine dose.

#. h/o CVA: stable.
Tthe patient has a recent history of CVA with previous 
admission. She did not exhibit signs of recurrence during this 
admission. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES

of hearing

SUMMARY: Mr. ___ is a ___ w/ PMH of HTN, ESRD on HD, CAD, DM2, 
schizophrenia, and depression who presented from rehab with AMS, 
bacteremia, NSTEMI in the setting of hypertensive emergency, 
stabilized on an oral antihypertensive regimen and worked up for 
NSTEMI and ruled out for CVA infarct, treated with IV 
antibiotics for suspicion of coag-negative Staph bacteremia, 
MSSA soft tissue infection, and E. coli UTI. His course was 
complicated by hematemesis for which he underwent 
esophagogastroduodenoscopy on ___ showing esophagitis, an ulcer 
at the GE junction with a vessel that was clipped, and an 
additional antral ulcer that was biopsied, without further 
evidence of bleeding subsequently.

#Hypertensive Emergency
Patient presented with BP 215/115 at ___ and was started on 
nicardipine gtt. His BP ranged from 127-196/68-132 in the ED. He

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___!  

Why was I admitted to the hospital?  
 
- You were admitted because you had high blood pressure and you 
were confused. 

What happened while I was in the hospital?  

- You received medicine to help lower your blood pressure. Due 
to your elevated blood pressure, you were found to be having a 
non ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (a kind of heart 
attack), which did not progress further after your blood 
pressure was under better control. You received an MRI of your 
___ which showed evidence of an old stroke, but no new strokes. 
There was concern for blood stream infection so you were treated 
with intravenous antibiotics.
- You underwent numerous tests, including multiple ultrasounds 
of your heart (echocardiograms). These showed signs of regional 
motion problems likely due to coronary artery disease (narrowing 
of the blood vessels around the heart). However, you did not 
undergo stenting given the likely chronic nature of your heart 
disease and due to concern for your gastrointestinal bleeding.
- You underwent regular hemodialysis on ___, and 
___ as scheduled.
- During this admission, you were also nauseous and vomiting 
blood. To evaluate the source of the bleeding, you were seen by 
the gastroenterologists and taken for esophagoduodenoscopy (EGD 
or "upper endoscopy"), and were found to have esophagitis 
(inflammation of the tube connecting your mouth to your stomach) 
and 2 different ulcers, one of which had a blood vessel that was 
clipped to prevent bleeding. you also had evidence of 
inflammation in your duodenum. For your ulcers, you were started 
on the medication pantoprazole.
-You were treated with intravenous antibiotics for suspicion for 
a bloodstream infection, a soft tissue infection at the site of 
your AV fistula, and a urinary tract infection.
-You developed diarrhea and were found to have C. difficile 
infection, for which you were started on treatment with oral 
vancomycin.
-You were also found to have difficulty speaking, and were 
evaluated by the speech language pathology team.
-You were found to have masses in both of your parotid glands 
(the largest glands in your cheeks that make saliva), which will 
require follow-up as an outpatient.

What should I do after leaving the hospital?  
-  Please take your medications as listed in discharge summary 
and follow up at the listed appointments. 

Thank you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish 
you all the best!  

Sincerely,

Your ___ Healthcare Team

Brief Hospital Course:
___ HLD, past CVA, and colon cancer initially resected in ___ 
(refused adjuvant chemo), now with metastatic disease including 
several brain lesions with edemea. He presented to the ED today 
with confusion and a febrile illness, likely secondary to 
dehydration and heat stroke. 
.
# Toxic metabolic encephelopathy: Confused, though largely just 
agitated and beligerent. This was initially thought to be 
related to his febrile illness and metabolic derangements. The 
patient was fluid resuscitated, had his blood sugars controlled 
and had his steroids briefly increased and quickly tapered. The 
patient's mental status improved to his baseline. 
. 
#. Fever: Unclear etiology although recorded at 103.8F rectally 
in the ED. UA negative. Culture and blood cultures negative. 
Head CT showed metastatic disease. CXR showed stable known 
metastatic disease. LP was negative. The pt received meningitis 
coverage in the ED but antibiotics were later held. The patient 
had no further episodes of fever during his hospital course. 
Thus, his fever was attributed to heat stroke. 
. 
#. Metastatic Colon Cancer: Mets to the brain. CT stable. 
Multiple brain lesions with vasogenic edema. The patients 
dexamethasone was increased from 2mg daily to 4mg QID while in 
house, this was tapered back down quickly to his home dose of 
2mg daily prior to d/c as there was no apparent increase in his 
cerebral edema on CT. He was continued on his home dosing of 
Keppra.   
.
#. Hyponatremia: Likely hypovolemic given insensible losses with 
fever, and very hot apartment without AC. It was also in the 
setting of likely hyperglycemia with potential some component of 
osmotic diuresis at home. The patient was given IVF and his Na 
improved from 125 to 129 while in house. 
.

these as ways to "play the game" to find him), and thought 
insertion, mostly in the context of symptoms of depression and 
anxiety surrounding her recent breakup with her boyfriend. Also 
with suicidal ideation. This was the patient's first psychotic 
break, and in light of her olfactory hallucinations, an EEG was 
performed to r/o temporal lobe epilepsy, and was negative. Other 
organic causes of psychosis essentially ruled out with negative 
CBC, LFTs, RPR, ___, and negative recent HIV test. Thus 
presentation was thought to be most consistent with major 
depressive disorder w/ psychotic features (vs. schizoaffective 
disorder vs. delusional disorder). She was placed on Risperdal 
in the ___, with almost immediate effect, and uptitrated to final 
dose of 4 mg qHS. She responded very well, with complete 
dissolution of her delusions, consistently denying any AH/VH/OH 
or IOR since admission to the unit. Endorsed SI in the ___, 
however on the unit she has no more SI. She refused initiation 
of Celexa in conjunction with the Risperdal, stating she did not 
feel depressed and would only like to take the Risperdal at this 
time, but will reconsider as outpatient. She expressed a 
commitment to medication compliance as well as following up with 
her outpatient treaters.

Patient was set up with new outpatient treaters, and is 
scheduled to see her therapist on ___, who will then refer to a 
psychiatrist. She was also set up with a Partial program at the 
___ starting with the beginning of her insurance. Group 
therapy programs were also recommended to her.

# Substance Use: No acute or chronic issues.

3) Medical:
The following acute medical problems were addressed during this 
hospitalization:
# Elevated WBC count with left shift: Initially presented with 
an elevated WBC count with left shift, however patient had 
negative ROS, UA was negative. Repeat CBC was negative, thus 
likely was due to a stress reaction.

# Implanon removal: patient has stated she would like her 
Implanon removed, mainly because she believes it to have incited 
her psychotic symptoms. Literature search was negative for 
connection between Implanon or active hormonal component and 
psychosis. Reinforced with the patient the lack of known 
connection between Implanon and psychosis, and suggested that 
procedure itself could have played role initiating psychotic 
symptoms. She was instructed to follow up with her OB/GYN (with 
whom she has an upcoming appointment) to have the Implanon 
removed if she wishes.

Patient was also instructed to make an appointment with her PCP 
for ___.

4) Legal/Safety:
CV signed and accepted on admission, and pt remained on such 
throughout the hospitalization.

Pt was calm and controlled on the unit. There were no 
safety/behavioral issues. She was kept on standard Q15 minute 
checks and unit restriction.

5) Social/Milieu:
Pt was encouraged to participate in unit’s groups/milieu/therapy 
opportunities. She consistently attended groups and socialized 
with peers, stating that she found great benefit in this, and 
enjoyed participating in the milieu. Family meeting was held 
with patient's father and cousin, addressed medication 
questions, relationship between Implanon and psychosis, and 
aftercare plan. Family was quite supportive, warm, and 
understanding about the patient's condition and would like her 
to continue with medications as well as with outpatient 
psychiatrist/therapist.

6) Disposition:
Patient was discharged to her parents' house, with plans to 
pursue nursing school again. She was optimistic about her 
future, and expressed commitment to medication compliance and 
following up with her new outpatient treaters. Her family was 
very supportive about the discharge plan. She was also very much 
looking forward to seeing her daughter, who will be living with 
her and her parents now as well.

Follow up was scheduled with therapist, partial program, PCP, 
and OB/GYN.

7) Risk Assessment:
At this point in time, patient is euthymic and no longer having 
self-injurious thoughts and not at acutely elevated risk of harm 
to self/others or inadequate self-care, and therefore no longer 
in need of inpatient treatment.

Static risk factors include previous suicidal attempt, family 
history of schizophrenia. Modifiable risk factors include 
untreated psychiatric illness which is now being treated with 
medication, and set up with outpatient providers. Protective 
factors include willingness to seek help, involved and 
supportive family, child with whom patient has a good 
relationship, ability to hold steady job, goals for going back 
to nursing school.
 
8) Prognosis:
Patient has a very good prognosis, primarily due to her 
willingness to adhere to her treatment plan, her supportive 
family, and her high level of functioning prior to admission. 
However further exploration of her depression and suicidality in 
the past, about which she was fairly guarded on this admission, 
will be beneficial to the patient to further explore her coping 
mechanisms and thought patterns.

.
Monitoring Ostomy output/Prevention of Dehydration:
-Keep well hydrated.
-Replace fluid loss from ostomy daily.
-Avoid only drinking plain water. Include Gatorade and/or other 
vitamin drinks to replace fluid.
-Try to maintain ostomy output between 1000mL to 1500mL per day. 

-If Ostomy output >1 liter, take 4mg of Imodium, repeat 2mg with 

each episode of loose stool. Do not exceed 16mg/24 hours
.

your final pathology report from you lung biopsy.

post-overlapping DES to ulcerated OM lesion, active tobacco use, 
hospitalized for hemodynamically stable anterolateral STEMI now 
post- uncomplicated revascularization of culprit LAD occlusion. 
Patient was in his usual state of health, with exception of 
subacute upper respiratory congestion, until four o'clock this 
morning when he, in no particular context, developed sudden, 
severe left-sided chest pain with concurrent left shoulder and 
upper arm pains, which he likened to prior cardiac events. He 
thinks he might have been diaphoretic for a whole day prior. ST 
elevations were first noted in V2-V4, prompting angiography, 
which revealed total occlusion of mid-LAD as well as chronic 
total occlusion of the mid-RCA and 70% stenosis OM1. DES was 
deployed to culprit LAD lesion and then loaded with ticagrelor. 
ST elevations later spread, involving V5-V6 and inferior leads 
too. He had residual chest pain ___ in severity 
post-revascularization, which lessened to ___ after addition of 
nitroglycerin gtt. MAP was likewise in the 100 to 110-range, 
hence nitroglycerine gtt. Patient reports chest pain has 
entirely subsided by arrival to the CCU. He is not forthcoming 
with medication compliance but admits to hiatus from routine 
cardiology care.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: constitutionally, he is fatigued, which he 
attributes to unrelenting upper respiratory congestion and

ACUTE ISSUES: 
==============
#STEMI, anterolateral
#reduced EF 28% 
#LV thrombus 
Presented to the ED in the setting of chest pain, stable without 
features of acute heart failure or cardiogenic shock, found to 
have STEMI (V2-V4 ST elevations on arrival). Cardiac cath 
revealed total occlusion of mid-LAD as well as chronic total 
occlusion of the mid-RCA and 70% stenosis OM1. DES was deployed 
to culprit LAD lesion and then loaded with ticagrelor. ST 
elevations later spread, involving V5-V6 and inferior leads. 
Required nitro gtt following cath. Started on dual anti-platelet 
therapy with ASA/ticagrelor (90 mg BID). TTE showed EF 28% and 
apical LV thrombus, started on apixaban 5mg BID. Was also 
discharged on atorvastatin 80mg, metop XL 100mg, lisinopril 10mg 
and spironolactone 12.5mg daily.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions
Brain Hemorrhage with Surgery

Surgery
•You underwent a surgery called a craniotomy to have blood 
removed from your brain. 
•Please keep your staples along your incision dry until they 
are removed.
•It is best to keep your incision open to air but it is ok to 
cover it when outside. 
•Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
•We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
•You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.
•No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
•If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 
•No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications
•Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
•You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This 
medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this 
medication as indicated on your discharge instruction. It is 
important that you take this medication consistently and on 
time. 
•You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
•You may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, and 
remembering new information.
•Emotional and/or behavioral difficulties are common. 
•Feeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood 
swings are also common.
•You may also experience some post-operative swelling around 
your face and eyes. This is normal after surgery and most 
noticeable on the second and third day of surgery.  You apply 
ice or a cool or warm washcloth to your eyes to help with the 
swelling. The swelling will be its worse in the morning after 
laying flat from sleeping but decrease when up. 
•You may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from 
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 
•Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

Headaches:
•Headache is one of the most common symptoms after a brain 
bleed. 
•Most headaches are not dangerous but you should call your 
doctor if the headache gets worse, develop arm or leg weakness, 
increased sleepiness, and/or have nausea or vomiting with a 
headache. 
•Mild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches but 
avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless prescribed 
by your doctor. 
•There are other things that can be done to help with your 
headaches: avoid caffeine, get enough sleep, daily exercise, 
relaxation/ meditation, massage, acupuncture, heat or ice packs. 


When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
•Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
•Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit.
•Nausea and/or vomiting.
•Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake.
•Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers.
•Seizures.
•Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak.
•Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg.

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:
•Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg.
•Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding.
•Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination.
•Sudden severe headaches with no known reason.

Brief Hospital Course:
Impression: Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with h/o cardiac 
arrest ___, afib on coumadin, diabetes, and COPD who presented 
with 2 days of SOB.

# Hypoxia/SOB:
Initially undifferentiated respiratory distress thought to be 
multifactorial from possible HCAP and COPD and she required 
BiPap support. Initialy CXR showed bilateral pleural effusions, 
L>R and possible LLL consolidation. Subsequent CXR showed 
complete white out of the left lung. She was treated empirically 
with vancomycin and cefepime and a 5 day steroid burst. She also 
had an elevated BNP implicating CHF in addition to possible 
pneumonia with fever and LLL consolidation on CXR  - thus she 
was diuresed with IV Lasix. A bronchoscopy was performed at 
bedside on ___ which removed a large mucus plug with 
improvement in her oxygen saturations. Culture from BAL washings 
grew MRSA so she was narrowed to vancomycin. She will completed 
a ten day course of vancomycin on ___. Likely she had a viral 
infection causing increased secretions and mucous plugging that 
she was unable to clear. Further, she likely was colonized by 
MRSA given her positive swab in ___. 

# AF with RVR:
Rate poorly controlled at rehab just prior to admission. 
Intermittently off coumadin in the past with h/o GI bleeding.  
Patient’s rate was difficult to control and blood pressures have 
been borderline-90s. Responded to metoprolol for rate control 
and we continued her coumadin dosing. She was discharged on 
100mg PO metoprolol succinate daily with a goal HR<110 bpm.

# systolic CHF:
EF 35%. Medical management included IV diuresis for frank volume 
overload on admission. She was then transitioned to a stable 
diuretic regimen of 20mg PO lasix daily. She was also continued 
on metoprolol. She was not started on an ace inhibitor but would 
benefit from one. Discharge weight 99 kg.

# bilateral pleural effusions: 
Likely related to volume overload from CHF. Expect improvement 
with continued diuresis with a stable diuretic regimen. Also 
with contributions from an infectious process (had evidence of 
viral infection on CT scan). 

# pericardial effusion: 
Hemodynamically insignificant. Pulsus between ___. 

# UTI: 
MRSA in urine culture. Unknown if patient symptomatic or 
colonized from chronic foley catheter.

# Anoxic encephalopathy and AMS: 
Altered on admission, most likely secondary to combination of 
infection and possible CO2 retention and likely was unable to 
compensate because of poor baseline. She was alert and oriented 
to name and hospital most days with confusion of the month/year. 
She displayed poor memory and attention.

# GERD: con't home PPI.

* optimization of heart failure regimen would include ace

* follow up pericardial and pleural effusions with imaging as

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was brought to the Operating Room on ___ where 
the patient underwent CABG x 4, AVR (tissue) with Dr. ___. 
See operative note for full details. Overall the patient 
tolerated the procedure well and post-operatively was 
transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and 
invasive monitoring.  
POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert and oriented and 
breathing comfortably.  The patient was neurologically intact 
and hemodynamically stable. Beta blocker was initiated and the 
patient was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight.  The 
patient was transferred to the telemetry floor for further 
recovery. Chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued without 
complication. He had a foley reinserted for urinary retention 
and was started on Flomax. He voided successfully after the 
foley was removed for the second time. He had a brief episode of 
atrial fibrillation. Lopressor was increased, Amiodarone bolus 
was given and the patient converted to sinus rhythm. He remained 
in sinus rhythm for the remainder of his hospital course. He was 
evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with 
strength and mobility. By the time of discharge on POD 4 the 
patient was ambulating freely, the wound was healing and pain 
was controlled with oral analgesics. The patient was discharged 
home with visiting nurse services in good condition with 
appropriate follow up instructions.
